150473922.review:
This game is a gem! I found it one day browsing the stream store. I decided to give it a try, and I am so happy I did. I had no idea that I would have so much fun playing this game. It does take some time to get use to the controls (I decided to use a controller instead of the keyboard); however, just keep playing and they get easier to remember and use. This game is such a nice experience.

My recommendation is to explore everywhere. The game encourages you do so. Talk to everyone you can. Help people and be kind to everyone. To me that was such a rewarding experience. I got so much happiness (a game mechanic that gives you health) by just helping all the characters I could. I was completely satisfied when I beat the game, but I still need to 100% it. 

You can tell the game developers put love into this game. The characters had all different personalities and interactions (the game gives me a Paper Mario Thousand Year Door feel). The world building is well done. I did feel like the NPCs and background characters were active in the world of the game which allows you to get sucked into the story and atmosphere of the game. Allow yourself to sit back and enjoy this amazing game!

In my opinion this game did not live up to the hype. I left the game feeling really let down and disliking it. I found myself depending on a guide just to complete the game so it felt like just a checklist until the game was over. I know this wasn't everyone's experience but I just wish there was more direction and help for where to go and what to do.
TLDR: Too easy to get lost and not know what to do.

147646749.review:
So much charme. Unique world building and art style. I don't know why it's described as a metroidvania, it doesn't have much to do with that genre. There are no abilities to be gained. The NPC interactions, puzzles and progression remind me much more of Monkey Island, but as a platformer with enemies and bosses. 

I really love the unique idea of the game and the execution is really good too, with a few minor issues.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]
[list]
[*] Amazing art style
[*] Worldbuilding
[*] Dialogue
[*] Funny dutch words
[*] Unique creative ideas
[*] Good boss fights
[*] Combat and platforming is well balanced in terms of difficulty
[/list]

[h1]Minor Issues[/h1]
[list]
[*] Control scheme is uncomfortable and unconventional by default: you jump with LT on Xbox controller. I tried to change it, but then some buttons (A) just stayed on the old layout in some cases, so things didn't work correctly anymore. I had to use the default layout, which I really didn't like.
[*] Some puzzles don't make a lot of sense and you have to guess. Especially the one near the end where you are underground was pretty bad. 
[*] After talking to an NPC, I often initiated the conversation again by accident (there is an additional misleading speech bubble at the end).
[*] I found both the shop interface and the player inventory to be unintuitive.
[*] The game makes you wait at a few points, which can become annoying.
[*] There are many (mostly cosmetic) items sold by vendors, but without "grinding", you hardly have enough money to buy anything.
[*] There are a few bugs (see other reviews).
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you're looking for something like Metroid or Hollow Knight, this is not it. But if you like a witty adventure game with some platforming and action, [b]I highly recommend it[/b].

145534262.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

wuppo is a metroidvania developed by snekflat and published by soedesco, a indie game dev/publisher. it released on steam in september of 2016. you play as a little fluff ball looking for a place to live. it has an amazingly unique art style, good music, and fun worldbuilding/writing. while the game seems like a game for little kids, or like some yoshi game that's easy even for toddlers, this is surprisingly complex and has some deep mechanics that keep the game feeling fresh and not just boring platforming challenges or anything too simplistic. 

there's a lot of overtly political themes that i was NOT expecting, but i actually enjoyed it as it added to the worldbuilding that was already good. the world itself is so believable immersive it's insane. it's fully realized and it genuinely doesn't feel like it belongs in a game like this. the controls are simplistic, but efficient and fun to use. there's no dash move, and that's one thing that sticks out as something that could've been very useful throughout the entirety of the game. the rest of the grips i have with wuppo are extremely minor and/or nitpicky to an annoying level probably, so i won't include them here. 

to sum it up, wuppo is an extremely underrated hidden gem for all of gaming, and that's not even taking into account that you can routinely find this on sale for 90% off making it $1.49 for what is a solid amount of content, especially for that price point. i definitely recommend grabbing this when you see it on sale, it will definitely surprise you like it did for me.

135642702.review:
Wuppo is more than a game, it is an artistic statement that challenges the very essence of the consumer's soul. Every character in this masterpiece of cinema expertly relates to a real world issue such as the underfunded school system, women's suffrage, and the military industrial complex. Every frame of this creation could be proudly displayed in the Louvre, each stroke of brush and scratch of pencil practically screaming with soul and artistic talent. I was in tears the entire time I played the game, not just from the unbelievably incredibly told story, with dare I say perfect character arcs and story beats, nay, it was also from the sheer beauty of the artistic style, every single element and aspect of this game can be dug into, having deeper meanings and dark undertones. Take for instance, Wuppo's constant smile, on the surface it  is an already obvious play on words of the overmonitization of art, yet as the story plays out and progresses, you learn that it is actually also BRILLIANTLY symbolicly a critique of the modern American family, which expands into other thought patterns throughout the game such as the existence of God and our responsibility of the earth.

All in all, it has a little something for everyone and it really makes you FEEL like Wuppo,
7/10

130865342.review:
I cannot recommend this game due to its very strange and insidious racial politics.

This is a story focused game whose opening exposition reveals the supposed racial hierarchy of the world: Wums are smart and cute and invented everything, fnakkers are dumb and violent and required banishing, and all the other races are only notable for their wum-serving abilities.

In any coherent story, this would constitute an obviously flawed and unsustainable status quo ripe for challenging, deconstructing and ultimately dismantling throughout our hero's adventures.

Except this game doesn't seem interested in any of that. The opening conceits about racial traits are denonstrated and reinforced throughout the game both by the dominant wums and by the other races.

The Blussers do nothing but meditate and tend Wum gardens, the splenkhakkers do nothing but maximise profits and take Wum money, and the fnakkers... dear god...

Okay so not only does the central conflict of this game NOT revolve around dispelling racial stereotypes and historical revisionism such that the races can be reunited and live together, but the ACTUAL conflict revolves around the primitive fnakkers bringing about the apocalypse by ritualistically paying tribute to a false god for the sole purpose of killing all the other races.

To add insult to injury, the fnakkers seem to be thinly veiled hateful stereotypes from the real world. They have gollywog-like appearances with shaggy hair and overgrown lips; they behave animalistically, knucklewalking, screaming, throwing rocks and wallowing in mud; they try to alternatively murder or boil alive the Wum protagonist if they wander undisguised into their territory; and they are portrayed as intrinsically violent, sadistic and backward.

Even the most intelligent among them admitting to destroying historical documents (which Wum scholars understand perfectly when shown), finding joy in others' misfortune, failing to even identify the basic function of a projector, and scorning electricity and tuned instruments in favour of brute strength and drums.

For a world that's meant to be both adorable and immersive, this a disgustingly mean-spirited and simplistic interpretation of fantasy race relations that hamstrings the game's storytelling possibilities and leads to one of the most left-field, pointless and insulting endings of any video game I've recently played.

It's a shame as the game has many positive elements as mentioned by other reviewers, but the weird in-universe justified racial feud that the game's world and plot rests on ultimately topples the whole experience and renders it a waste of time.

128178587.review:
Fat, lazy [i]Wum[/i] is kicked out from his room in a Wumhouse because of his unhealthy love for an ice cream -he keeps ordering it to his room, but as the transport tubes got clogged up because of it, he needs to pick it up himself down in the lobby. As [i]Wums[/i] hold items on their heads he leaves a huge mess behind him! That's enough for the Wumhouse manager and our little hero is thrown out from his balcony! Out in the wilderness begins his search for a new home. And maybe he will even solve a few mysteries from the past and even save the world before an unexpected destruction.

[i]Wuppo[/i] is a charming game full of funny characters and silly moments. Both hand-drawn graphics and catchy soundtrack suit the game well. Wearing items on your head is a great feature and I have enjoyed changing my appearance through the game. The items are also nicely varied (purely cosmetic, weapons, food, for stealth…) and it was fun to try them out. Lore of the world is interesting and you can uncover it even more by collecting filmstrips which record the most important historic events, basic information about the world or some mysterious writings from the long forgotten past.

Gameplay wise it's a metroidvania. There are no basic enemies, except for some pests in one location, but the game is filled with a lot of bosses! Some of them are mandatory for a story progression, others are optional. Few of them are rather hard even on lower difficulty, but luckily there is no penalisation for dying, you just start the fight again. Playing on hardest was quite a challenge, but still fun.

Whole game can be experienced in co-op as the second player can assume the role of our sidekick, a talkative bird Denksnavel. Sadly his possibilities are quite limited - he can fly around and attack (some of the enemies can't be hurt by him, but he can at least protect our [i]Wum[/i] by blocking some of the projectiles - that was pretty handy actually). And that’s all for the second player. Also he is bound to us as there is no split screen and he can't leave the screen on his own. This part is lacking, it would be a lot more fun if there could be two [i]Wums[/i] together. Quite disappointing is the fact that your friend can't help you in Boss rush… yeah, I suck in it on my own. XP

All in all we have rather enjoyed the [i]Wuppo[/i] and can recommend it!

124846505.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Wuppo: The Definitive Edition is a game developed by Knuist & Perzik and published by SOEDESCO. It was released on Sep 29th 2016, with first development footage (as found on the “Perzik & Knuist” channel) available all the way back in March 2013. The game follows a nameless protagonist, who’s a “wum”, one of the many creatures inhabiting the colorful world of Wuppo. Thrown out of his house, he’s thrust into the wild, to brave a perilous world of adventure and secrets galore.
For brevity’s sake, here is a list of PROs and CONs, before the more long-form review:

[h2]CONS[/h2]
- A little obtuse sometimes (x)
- Grindy coin farming
- Some bosses are a little more hit or miss
- Wait times (i.e. for the [spoiler]Popo Train[/spoiler], the [spoiler]Wondersplenk[/spoiler] rides and public transport in [spoiler]Popo City[/spoiler])
- Length of passages (e.g. the bridge in [spoiler]Popo City[/spoiler])
- Way too long sequences (e.g. performing a job that requires you to throw 150 newspapers onto different wums, [spoiler]Fnakball[/spoiler])
→ Exploring can (at times) be a bit boring and tedious
→ Kinda feels like the game is wasting your time/testing your patience at times
- Weird sound mixing (particularly the sounds of one boss – [spoiler]Breevis[/spoiler], and hit sounds); brief, very loud distortion, when using fast travel
- easy to skip too much dialogue, by trying to fast forward it, via LMB (using spacebar can mitigate this a bit)
- game often starts minimized, and locks cursor in the top left corner of the screen, you have to fiddle around with Alt + Tab to get into the actual game
- Lots of actions are slow or tedious (such as having to go through the menu every time to sell stuff)
- Fast travel unlocks only shortly before the game’s ending, and some locations still require quite a long trek to get to

[h3]Minor:[/h3]
- Some dialogue was off-screen a few times, i.e. the cutscene after the final boss fight, getting [spoiler]tourist info in Popo City[/spoiler]
- You have to figure out where every fast travel point takes you on your own
- Water is poisonous at fishing docks, even after clearing Kneft infestation (the rest of the water no longer hurts you)

[h2]Neutral:[/h2]
~ The base difficulty of the game is pretty easy

[h2]PROS[/h2]
+ Fantastic, unique visual style
+ Awesome OST by Thomas de Waard
+ A world that feels incredibly alive (lots of other characters, just walking around, quite a bit more populated than the usual game world)
+ Enormous amount of attention to detail
+ A particularly pleasant story, with imaginative twists and turns, which also happens to touch on some interesting topics, like self-actualization, predestination, division, friendship, the value we place on work (plus some other subtle political and philosophical topics)
+ An unexpected amount of lore, and really great lore at that
+ Really witty and well-written dialogue
+ Fun secrets (though, refer to “x”)
+ Some very interesting bosses and encounters (+ One super unique boss!)
+ Combat is pretty fun, if very simple, for the most part
+ Really great, miscellaneous mechanics, and sections utilizing different, sometimes one-off puzzle ideas
+ Constant updates, very active and passionate dev team, adding new content every once in a while (though this may have ceased with the release of “Definitive Edition”, I am unsure)


[h1]Review[/h1]
Wuppo is what you get, when someone has an idea in middle school about wanting to make an incredible game, from their childhood notebook full of doodles. It’s a beautiful, tried and true method — tried, for one, by Eiichiro Oda, creator of the Manga “One Piece”. In this way, Wuppo is also an exercise in love and authenticity. The art of the game is inspired, it lives and breathes and marches to the rhythm of its own heart. The score by Thomas de Waard is a diverse selection of pieces, all setting the stage for the equally idiosyncratic visuals, characters, environments and gameplay. It’s a game full of laughs and comedy, and quickly, humorously, wittly resolved conflict, and yet, it still has interesting things to say, mayhap even teach. Brought to a point, Wuppo is an almost iconoclastic sweep into the often serious, dark and brooding artistic environment. It is jovial in a way, which can scarcely be likened to anything other than a Disney movie or Nintendo property.
It is a game I had my problems with, a myriad of them, as evident in the bullet points. Some of these problems are simple differences in philosophy (I’ll elaborate in a moment) and others genuine problems I have with the flow of the game (and some smaller bugs, here and there). Chief among these issues, is a general sense of your time being wasted. There is an elevator to get into one of the main areas of the game, but, like all public transport throughout Wuppo, it works on an actual timer, making you wait multiple minutes, as you would in real life, to catch the elevator, and then making you sit in it, for quite a while longer, till you finally reach your desired destination. In the following area, called [spoiler]Popo City[/spoiler] you will find trams, these too, work on a timer, making you wait each time to cross a giant bridge in the center, or making you walk the bridge’s length; a length that rivals the comedy of the infamous ladder of Metal Gear Solid 3 (at least I think it’s 3, never played the games), but it only does so the first or second time you have to cross it. The shell shock of repeated tedium hits you soon enough.
These wait times have actually been explained by the developers in the Steam discussion forums [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/400630/discussions/0/350544272220383836/#c350544272221403914]here[/url]. To paraphrase briefly: [spoiler]Popo City[/spoiler] is meant as a cinematic setpiece, and riding to it for only a few seconds would be inconsistent with its image as a faraway place, thus causing ludo-narrative dissonance. The wait times for certain [spoiler]theme park attractions[/spoiler] are based off the developer’s experiences of excitement, while waiting in line for a [spoiler]ride[/spoiler] in real life. The case they make is a fascinating one. Putting emphasis on wait times as a form of artistic expression is quite striking in video games, not unlike the deliberate use and exploration of silence in music (John Cage) or the study of negative spaces in art.
Though I enjoyed what the developers attempted to do here, I still found myself, on the basic level of enjoying or not enjoying something, to be rather annoyed by this at times, and felt like my time was being wasted a little, and my patience tried. Similar feelings were evoked by some of the game’s activities (e.g. jobs) and coin farming — which I felt could’ve been streamlined much more — as well as other miscellaneous actions.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Nevertheless, going beyond the basic, knee-jerk responses I had, Wuppo was an incredible game, with amazing dialogue, a beautiful, eccentric world, with equally interesting characters and expansive lore, with an overall flair all around it; combat, which — while simplistic — somehow fits the “middle school" feeling I spoke of at the beginning of this review perfectly.
Wuppo is an effort of many years of hard work and love. As an artist, I may only tip the hat to  Knuist & Perzik, as well as everyone else who helped create this splendid piece of art. The game pushes the boundaries and experiments, and while I couldn’t find it within myself to 100% it, for reasons of personal tedium and time constraints, I can recommend it beyond the shadow of a doubt. I feel it is always important to see what makes a piece of art special, and what the artists were trying to say, make you feel, create — going beyond the simple “like”/”dislike” paradigm. So despite my slightly mixed experience:

[h3]Much Love To Knuist & Perzik — as well as SOEDESCO — For Sharing Their Beautiful Art With The World![/h3]

124127762.review:
Wuppo is a 2D metroidvania with a charming visual style but unfortunately that is the only good thing about it. Game has minimum combat and character development as you could expect from a metroidvania. Instead it is focused on story, dialogs and quests. That is not a bad thing by itself but... story makes no sense at all, some random events happen one after another and none of them is actually interesting. Character are boring and dialogs never go farther than jokes and gags.

Game has almost no common enemies and combat but it has plenty of bosses. Solid boss fights could compensate for a mediocre gameplay but most bosses are plain bad. Early game bosses are pathetically easy and basic while late game ones are hard for all the bad reasons including bad camera angles, poorly telegraphed attacks, lots of RNG etc.

Wuppo is not terrible but it is just boring to play. Nothing really happens, you do boring stuff for no reason and with no reward and keep doing it until it is (finally) finished. Not recommended.

112666806.review:
Wuppo is kind of difficult for me to describe because it really is its own thing. One of the press blurbs on this Steam page for is is a quote from PCGamer stating, "Wuppo, the most overlooked 'hidden gem' on Steam." That feels like an accurate sentiment, hyperbole aside.

It's a fun little platformer with some shooting and almost Metroidvania elements to it, as well as a small open-ish world to explore with a carnival, a few towns, and plenty of hidden little secrets. You can visit shops to customize and dress up your protagonist and upgrade your tools or just buy useless silly things. It's light-hearted and fun, giving kind of a warm fuzzy feeling to the whole thing. It's almost a childlike wonderment.

I honestly have had significant difficulty figuring out how best I want to summarize and review Wuppo and I think I have to give in and say: Wuppo is a fun warm and fuzzy game with some light platforming, a small but fun world to explore, and engaging experience. I finished it in roughly 6 hours and in that time I enjoyed every moment of the game. I only finished with around 57% of the game completed and having missed 5 of the optional bosses so if you're looking for even more it's there to be found.

I sincerely with a smile on my face recommend Wuppo and cannot precisely pin down why. More a feeling than a thought, and Wuppo feels great.

This was certainly impressive. The world is very lively, and it does not feel like it revolves around you. Folks run around, jumping up and down, buying stuff at shops, working, etc. Many areas are completely optional, some quite out of the way, and the characters are usually charming even when being pricks. :D

Gameplay is mostly fun too. It isn't quite a "metroidvania", but the game has a plethora of "wearable" objects which can be used in all sorts of situations. Downsides: a couple of items are not explained -- not as much as in "where to use this" (I love to discover such mechanics), but as in "what buttons do I press to get this going"; and, well, waiting for public transportation is not a fun game mechanics. But all in all, an enjoyable game and clearly a labor of love.

Score: 78/100.

109925646.review:
Ah, Wuppo. I've played this game a couple of times and it is certainly one of my utmost favourites. A lot of times with games they're not as good the second time around, much less third and so on, however with Wuppo it's always seemed to be just as good every time I play it. There's a lot of awesome stuff about it, more than I could neatly fit into this review.

For starters, it features some of the best world-building I've ever seen. The places have a feel to them, a mood that is similar to how real life places sometimes have a mood, their own personality that you can feel. Plus the inhabitants of the world often have their own things they are doing, going about their business as if you were indeed just another stranger. All of the characters feel real and interesting in their own way, and everything you encounter makes sense to be there. Take for example bosses: a lot of times in games you may find a boss at some place and it makes sense why they are in that location, but not really why they are there at that time, or what they were doing before you got there, they just exist and you defeat them. In Wuppo all of the bosses contextually made sense and fit perfectly into the story, while also being engaging to fight. I just love how creative the game is, and how all of these great things together really make you feel a part of the world. 

Then there's the cute, endearing artstyle of the game. I haven't seen any games (apart from An Untitled Story) that feature a look like this. The way it is all wobbly and fuzzy and cute, I love it! Its broad selection of palettes brings joy to my heart. Also, I should mention that the funpack for this game has a Wuppo science video, and it is glorious.

On a different note, there is also the delightful soundtrack, which compliments the moods and events happening in the game, while also being great to listen to on its own. There are some particularly fresh tunes from the game's radio (because Wuppo has its very own radio station), which I listen to regularly. Speaking of nice sounds, one thing that really helps to sell the world of Wuppo is the ambience. Whether it's the sound of a tram leaving or just the local critters, having all that happening makes the world feel lively and rich, I love simply being in it.

The worst part about Wuppo is that I bought it on sale ;o; (         WHY!!?                           WHYYYYYYY?!!!!!). Do not make the same mistake as I did, dear reader; If the game is on sale, don't buy it, wait till it's full price. To close off, in the words of Bufter, "Buy Wuppo and you will be very happy."

107505668.review:
I really didn't expect to spend so much time on this game.
 This is a full on 2D Metroidvania with tons of characters and quests and dialogue. The gameplay itself is passable, but just the variety of locations, and situations you get thrown into is fun. 
Quests can vary from a gladiator fight to saving cooks from their own creation to becoming a paper boy in a city to solving puzzles in a haunted ancient ruin to evicting uncooperative tenants to diving deep underwater to fight a sea monster. This game really goes places, it's a bit surreal thinking back at it all now. 

Especially the first 5 mins of the game are hilarious, tho I felt the first half of the game was quite barren story wise but it picked up again later in the game. So you do need some patience with the game. 

The races, lore, and even the origin story of the world are actually really consistent and encourage exploration and even theorycrafting. 

The inventory is a clunk fest, especially the further you get in the game and the more items you carry. And the controller support has a bug where sometimes it just likes to shoot to the left randomly which is a shame cause otherwise it's perfectly controller friendly. So ye, gotta use Mouse and Keyboard. 
 There's also so much to keep track off if you would want to 100% this game. There is no log for side quests and so keeping track of those is entirely up to the player and you are really bombarded with story from all sides sometimes it's very hard not to get overwhelmed. 
It may be a Metroidvania but sometimes you're literally spending an hour in a town just talking to people ;D
Not sure if the average Metroidvania fan appreciates that. But you can skip some NPCs and locations which is what I did, especially Wondersplenk. It was too much lol

Different, but good.

107018939.review:
[b][u]This game was reviewed using Version 1.0.37. Your experience on future versions may vary.[/u][/b]

[h3][b][u]Short Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] An underrated metroidvania filled to the brim with content, though not always the best at guiding you through it all. With a great visual style, expansive soundtrack, and at least 7-8 hours of main story story content alone, it's well worth its $15 price tag even if you aren't pushing for 100% completion.

[b][u]NOTE[/u]: This game comes with a bit of an [u]epilepsy warning[/u], as some sequences have rapid flashing visuals that cannot be disabled. For a detailed explanation, see below.[/b]

[h3][b][u]Long Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] [i]Wuppo[/i] is a metroidvania game about a little 'Wum' who travels the world in search of a new home, and gets involved in a bunch of shenanigans along the way. [b]The game juggles a healthy mix of platforming, combat, and puzzle solving, and it balances it all very well[/b], making sure that none of these gameplay elements feel underdeveloped. Along with a decent-sized main story to run through, [b]the game is chock-full of secrets and side content[/b] to keep you busy, and nearly all of them provide a reward worth your time if you choose to pursue them. All of this is made more fun to run through thanks to the [b]wide range of colorful characters[/b] that populate the game, making sure every new area you visit provides you with a unique experience. Top things off with a [b]charming hand-drawn art style[/b] reminiscent of Paper Mario series, as well as a a [b]large and pleasant soundtrack[/b] throughout, and you've got a game that's almost certain to give you a good time.

Good as it is, though, it's not without its problems. While being filled with content is certainly a positive thing, [i]Wuppo[/i] occasionally struggles to guide the player through it. [b]It doesn't always do the best job at steering you in the right direction[/b], both for secrets and story content, so you may find yourself running around in circles or consulting a walkthrough if you miss a stray piece of dialogue that hints at where to go next. Post-release patches have alleviated this issue somewhat (especially for completionists), but still doesn't always get it right, so don't blame yourself if you wind up getting stuck every once in a while. For those opting for 100% completion, also know that you'll almost definitely need to spend time grinding for money; and doing so is a slog no matter how you approach it, as even the fan-discovered money farming tricks still take a long time. It's not a huge issue, but [b]the need to grind for money made 100% completion drag in some parts more than I would have liked[/b].

At the start of this review, I said that [b]this games comes with an unofficial [u]epilepsy warning[/u][/b], as some parts of it involve sequences of bright, flashing lights and/or strobe effects that cover the entire screen and cannot be avoided or disabled during your playthrough. They don't always come with much warning before they happen, so I've outlined where in the game these take place, and what to look out for to signal that they're about to happen. Obviously, some spoilers ahead:
[list]
[*]Early game: [spoiler]The first major boss of the game is this giant stone idol, and its death animation--which occurs once he runs out of health and starts floating towards the center of the chamber--causes the screen to quickly flash white for a couple seconds.[/spoiler]

[*]Late game: [spoiler]Once you reach the bottom of Redav Kned's Guest House, the underground ruins under Bliekopolis, you'll find an altar with five pedestals, and you need to place food on all five of them to activate it. Doing so summons a spirit with a very bright light and some minor strobe effects that slowly build in intensity for a bit. This sequence happens again a little later, albeit with a bit less intensity.[/spoiler]

[*]Late game: [spoiler]After you summon the spirit a second time, it gives you something called a Warp Mask. Each use of the mask requires you to hold the Use button as a random sequence of symbols starts to strobe quickly across the screen. It's probably the least intense of the visuals here, but gets a warning just to be safe.[/spoiler]

[*]Final boss: [spoiler]Just as the final boss fight is coming to an end, bright flickering lights will appear randomly across the screen as a character is summoned to deliver the final blow. The cutscene that follows contains an extremely intense sequence of bright flashing lights and strobe effects, bad enough that it could strain your eyes even if you aren't at risk of epileptic seizures. If you reach this point and you are at risk, fight normally until the last bubble of light (next to the boss's health) begins to drain--the music will pick up in intensity and you'll notice flickering lights come into view once the sequence is starting. Eat a health item if you can (as the boss will keep firing), then look away from the screen and keep pushing the A button until the white noise that accompanies the cutscene stops and the game goes near silent.[/spoiler]
[/list]
This isn't an exhaustive list of "epilepsy warning" sequences, just ones that caught my eye while I was playing, so feel free to let me know if I missed anything. These aren't something that would make me tell people to avoid this game altogether, but they should come with some kind of in-game warning beforehand, or means to disable the effects altogether.

For my save file on normal difficulty, [b]it took me about 7 hours to beat the main story, and another 6-7 hours to reach 100% file completion[/b]--and that's not including the time I could spend beating the game on harder difficulties or the Boss Run mode you unlock in the post-game. While the game had its ups and downs, I found myself enjoying the game much more often than not. [b][u][i]Wuppo[/i] is an overall charming game that's packed with content, and it's well worth the $15 price tag for how much you can get out of it.[/u][/b] What Knuist & Perzik made could certainly be considered an underrated gem, and I hope that time will bring more deserved recognition to this game as well as their future endeavors.

[quote]For more game reviews, check out my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42524563/]Curator page[/url]![/quote]

102763873.review:
Wuppo is a fun metroidvania about finding a place to live. It has great art style, amazing music, fun worldbuilding and writing. But that's not why I'm recommending it. I'm doing that because this game triggered some kind of mystical revelation within me.

Let me try to explain why. The game's setting, characters, music, and the combination thereof create this very strong feeling of being in a living, breathing world. Getting lost in Popo City, waiting at the train station, lazing about in the Wumhouse. This is not a game board that exists for you to play in, it's a world that you just happen to be a part of. And this is a world that welcomes you, that loves you - even if you disagree sometimes.

It's a very optimistic game. There are conflicts, there is danger, but in the end the game whispers "it will all be okay" into your ear - and you believe it. 

Everything else, the gameplay, the plot, they're all just means with which the game conveys its optimism. As such, they almost tend to blend in. That's a good thing, though - it 'flows', so you never have those 'oh, it's a game' moments. Which is all we can ask for, really. If you ever played Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door, you probably have an idea what I'm talking about, except it's much stronger here.

Oh, and before I played this, I was roughly aware of this game and it seemed generic and uninteresting (wacky funny creatures? yaaawn). I was so, so wrong. I implore you: do not make the same mistake as I did. Play Wuppo. It will change your life. And if it won't, you'll at least play a pretty decent game.

102600700.review: Wuppo is such a special game to me, it is one of those rare games that effortlessly immerses you into its world with brilliant and funny dialogue, incredible exploration, and charming puzzles with brief intermissions of tense combat. This game is relentlessly enjoyable with some of the funniest, most memorable characters I’ve ever seen in a game brought to life by the whimsical and endearing art style and amazing soundtrack which gave every area a distinct atmosphere and mood. This is the most I’ve been invested in an indie game’s world since Hollow Knight and the number of details in the world is stupidly high like a real-time transportation system and unique dialogue based on when you encounter them. It progresses like a mix of a Metroidvania and a classic JRPG with a heavy emphasis on environmental puzzles, dialogue, exploration, and bullet hell boss battles. Due to this variety this game’s main quest never really gets old and the pacing is pretty damn good as a result. Exploration is encouraged with the vast amount of side quests, bosses, and collectibles with a great progression system and almost perfectly designed economy with Popocity being the location where the stars align with great exploration, puzzles, bosses, and dialogue. This is honestly such an amazing game and one of the best indies I’ve ever played, while it does have some polishing missteps, they are pretty negligible and it doesn't drag the game down. I never would have bought this game in a million years if not for a very special recommendation from someone so I’m telling you now that you should play this game, it already holds such a special place in my heart and is one of my favorite games and probably the funniest game I’ve ever played.

102098555.review:
What I enjoy about this game:
[list]
[*] Adorably cute graphics and excellent soundtrack and sound effects.
[*] Most locations in the Wuppo world are joyful to explore.
[*] NPCs in most locations just take care of their own affairs without being disturbed by the presence of our protagonist. It really gives me the feeling of blending in and being one of the community of this wonderful Wuppo world.
[*] Tons of heartwarming/funny side quests/dialogues/interaction with the NPCs.
[*] Tons of save points, especially before and after each boss or difficult-to-get places.
[*] Filmstrips spread throughout the map tell a coherent and vivid background story of the Wuppo world.
[*] You need to queue up for [spoiler]theme park (the Wondersplenk) attractions and entrance to the city (the Popocity)[/spoiler]. You also need to wait for [spoiler]trains, trams, and the fall of night for certain quests[/spoiler]. I know lots of players hate this, but I find  it a nice touch since it makes the Wuppo world feel even more immersive.
[*] No missable collectibles/locations/achievements.
[/list]

What I don't like or even hate about this game:
[list]
[*] Certain locations or collectibles require performing precision platform actions. This makes the game less casual than it should be.
[*] Boss fights are not very interesting, especially the final one.
[*] The first (the Wumgarden) and the last final location (the Sinkhole) are quite boring to explore.
[*] The final puzzle [spoiler](Redav Kned's Guesthouse)[/spoiler] is notoriously difficult. It is mostly nonsensical and is supposed (according to the devs) to be solved by trial and error.
[*] The game does not give enough guidance on how to progress. You have to explore every nook of a location and interact with each NPC to have a clearer idea on what's going on and what the game needs you to do. I have to frequently rely on guides and walkthrough.
[*] Some achievements requires farming or RNG events and therefore are really grinding to get.
[*] The game does not display correctly when you change resolution.
[/list]

To be honest, I almost rage-quit and refund the game at the beginning when I wander in a mostly empty location (the Wumgarden), jumping up and down in the jungle, avoiding thorns and dying a couple of times without meeting a new NPC. Consider that I got the game 92% off, I decide to keep it and to press on. Well, my effort pays off when the game just gets better and better after the garden. The story and the world progressively unfold and the game becomes really intriguing.

Overall, I do not regret the dozen of hours I spent on this game and I strongly recommend it to other players Just a little caveat: do not expect to rush through this game, otherwise you cannot reap any pleasure from it. This game certainly has a similar vibe to A Short Hike, another great casual exploration & adventure game. Be patient and play it casually, then you will experience the joy of being a wum in the Wuppo world.

The game also has a day/night cycle and tries to make the world look like it's alive, which is pretty cool, but with how difficult it is to travel that felt more like an inconveince to me.

99237044.review:
Wuppo is a good game with a flawed design.

You're a wum. A messy wum. You get kicked out of your apartment because you're a messy goon. You then spend the first quarter of the game attempting to get back into your apartment. I'm not going to bother describing anything else that happens in the game because it's simply too difficult to describe what's happening in this game.

Where Wuppo excels is that it is an incredibly unique/creative game. It's cute and charming. The boss fights are well done. Dialogue ranges from well done and humorous to slow and plodding... which also describes the pacing of the game. You're going to be exploring for most of it and having no idea what's going on or what you're doing.

Wuppo's main issue is that it was designed poorly. The menus are a hassle. The controls are a bit awkward as well but you get used to them over time and they're not terrible, just awkward. 

The game has a map you can pull up to get around, but it's not particularly helpful in helping you navigate a lot of the time since rooms don't show where they connect. There's also no quick travel points... until you get to the very end of the game just before the final boss. This isn't a big deal as you don't need to backtrack very often, but it's weird that they threw in a quick travel system but don't give you access to it until the very end of the game.

The game has puzzles and there are a couple that are obscure for no real reason. They're not hard, simply placing objects on pedestals, but they're needlessly cryptic. 

I see some people complain about parts with waiting and while that might be bad if true, there's only one part you actually have to wait and sit around. That's for a train that takes you underground. Once you go underground, you don't need to come back up. So it's one segment and there's even a clock showing you when it's going to arrive so you can go off and do something else until it shows up, which isn't that long in the first place. I don't remember there being any other part in the game that requires waiting around. Every other part with waiting, such as getting in lines at the theme park, are 100% optional.

Wuppo is above average to good. It basically boils down to this. If you're looking for something unique, this is it. If the issues mentioned above are off-putting, then don't get it.

98997563.review:
EDIT: i have since 100%'d this game and i still love it dearly, but i will not be changing my review until the issues i had are addressed. restarting and playing through the whole game again because of bad rng was something *I* was willing to do, but not something i would expect of everyone playing this game, and as such my review will stay negative until the issues are fixed.

i love this game and i recommend you to play it if you're a fan of charming worlds or boss rush games, it does these very well and it's a very fun adventure game.

what i DONT recommend is for you to 100% this game. ever.
spoilers ahead so read with caution.
popocity is so terribly designed and is the killer if your first 100% run, no matter WHAT. you will HAVE to 100% this game twice because of the event involving reaching 10,000 credits. when you reach popocity it's already around 8,000, and will tick up over time so even if you do nothing it will eventually reach 10,000. why is this an issue? simple, many events can ONLY be completed BEFORE it reaches 10,000 and (unlike most events) CANNOT be completed after you beat breevis. the worst example is the kneft invasion, which is where i lost my run. 5.5 hours in and i have literally done EVERYTHING ELSE up to this point, all i had to do was a couple of missions i knew could be completed after breevis, the fried kneft happiness point, and the kneft invasion. i had totally forgotten the kneft invasion was a thing and spent so long trying to get the bad kneft from fishing (nothing but good fish hooks, by the way) that the city reached 10,000. so before i went to fight breevis i figured i would take care of the kneft invasion. but for SOME REASON the kneft invasion GOES AWAY WHEN YOU REACH 9,999. not after breevis, which is what would make sense, but RIGHT when the city locks up. so if you take too long doing the mandatory events for 100% you are PERMANENTLY LOCKED OUT OF 100%ING THE GAME AND MUST RESTART. not to mention, i was playing on INSANE MODE. so if i want to get back to where i was, i would have to replay 2/3rds of the game all over again and make sure i did ABSOLUTELY EVERYTHING on a TIMER to make sure that i didn't miss anything and would have to repeat it all over again. 100%ing this game is terribly designed and ruined all good graces i had for this insanely charming and fun game. if you play this game, for the love of god do not 100% it.
98997563.developer_response:
Sorry to hear you had such a bad time 100%ing it. However, you should be able to fight the kneft infestation after you've reached the sinkhole. You just can't do it during the Popo City event you described, because all credit counters are locked. Once they're re-enabled you're good to go. 

There are some events in the game that you can skip or miss, but none of them should affect your ability to 100% the game.

97693715.review:
This is the game in my library that I'd say most closely fits the description of "hidden gem".
I am unsure about how this game even ended up in my library. It probably was included in some humble bundle. I certainly never would have thought of buying it.
One day, as I was pondering over which game to play in my ever-increasing steam backlog, I threw a few dice to let fate decide for me, and fate playfully decided to present me with Wuppo. At first I thought: "No no no! Even I have some standards, I might be playing crap every other day but I'm still not going to play that!". But somehow, I managed to go against that impulse and give it a try, and boy was I right to do so.
Funny absurd humor, unique art style, good gameplay, daunting challenges, this game has it all. It's by no mean a masterpiece, but man is it good.
This game is a very unique blend of what I'd call point-and-click-style exploration and humor with tight and challenging boss fights. The art style and the absurd humor make me feel nostalgic as they remind me of my childhood flash and RPG maker games. Like Shadow of the Colossus, the bosses are basically the only action part of the game, and here, they come as a reward, or a sort of break from the other half of the game, the world's exploration.
Anyway. In case the message didn't come through: I recommend it.

96520609.review:
Wuppo is a really cute metroidvania game that doesn’t take itself too seriously and the game’s dialogue as well as characters are fun and have a lot of personality. The problem is that this game has some really big fundamental problems that keep me from recommending this game even to the most hardcore metroidvania fans. 

1. No in-game map: In my opinion, every metroidvania game MUST have an fully integrated in-game map of some kind, because one of the main ideas of metroidvania is to open new areas with different skills and items, which then takes the player forward in the game and makes the player stronger as the player is progressing in the game. In addition, metroidvania games usually contain a very large area / map where player then progresses. Because of this, other metroidvania games (even the more older metroidvania games) have a in-game navigation map that tells you where to go roughly. In this game, though, it’s very hard to understand where you must go to, what this object does, what area I’m in, and so on. This then leads to situations where you have to travel around a large area several times without being sure where to go and what places I’ve already explored. In the Ori game series this was done well, as one had to understand the ways to get somewhere, but players were given the opportunity to use the map and navigate through it. Ori also has a really nice navigation system which tells the player where to go next (roughly). This may sound like a minor problem but trust me, this aspect can completely ruins otherwise really great metroidvania games when the player is frustrated with a very poor navigation mechanics.

2. map design: The next very annoying side of the game is that sometimes it is very difficult to understand which object a player can jump to and which objects are so to speak "transparent", i.e. which are only part of the background. For example, in Ori games, it was very easy to understand which objects were available to the player and which platform to jump to. The game is also not helped by the fact that the objects used in the game blend into the background too well because of the art style that the game developers have taken for this game. This doesn't sound like a really big problem at first, but later in the game this becomes VERY problematic for the player. This is after all a metroidvania PLATFORMER. 

If these aspects had been fixed times ago, then I think this might be a really good game full of personality. Unfortunately, I have to say that this is not a very good platformer nor is it a good metroidvania game. For these reasons I do not recommend this game in a current state.

95252982.review:
It's got an art style clearly inspired by the Paper Mario series, yet Wuppo proves to be more than just a homage. There's a cute and humorous world to explore that gets you joyful and nostalgic.
It's a straight forward game on normal difficulty but that doesn't mean it's boring, as the charm of the world can be felt throughout, with its' Dutch naming convention which brings back a portion of childhood. It's fun for all ages.
Your main means of attack is the gumgumgun, which shoots colourful ammunition automatically.
Though, other weapons can be encountered later on. The game also allows for some minor customisation for your weapons.
After completing the main story, you can unlock the Boss Run Mode, a fun little mode which allows for replay value, and does have some surprising depth to it.

Technical performance is solid, though a note to laptop owners; the game seems to default to integrated graphics, be sure to go to Nvidia control panel to change that in case performance seems poor.
Still, the gameplay appears to be mostly unaffected by bugs, though I have encountered a softlock in the Kneft sewer boss where the fight would not begin, but it was easy to fix by loading a save point.

Wuppo sits at 3000+ reviews on Steam, yet is a rather obscure game despite that. It is a shame as it's a lovely game waiting to be discovered by the masses, it's 90% off on a Steam sale and not many games can be bought for such cheap and be fun.

Wuppo is a console ported 2D retro platformer/metroidvania with hand drawn MS-Paint style art.  Evicted from your home, you must find a new one by platforming around the place with some lightweight inventory management and a lot of clicky dialogue with NPCs. 

While there's 4K support here, it doesn't make much difference because the system art assets are low resolution.  The MS Paint artwork might be appealing to some, but it comes across, along with the rest of the 2D only game construction, as somewhat lazy and distracting.   Controls are also a problem, some controllers don't work properly with the game, but at least KB controls work.

There's an issue with racism towards the end of the game that isn't handled well and has caused some complaints.  Finally the $15 USD price tag is exceedingly high for this console ported 2D bundle stuffer.

85800780.review:
I rate Wuppo: Definitive Edition 3/5. Eh, it’s okay I guess.

Wuppo is an extremely cute, satirical, side-scrolling adventure game featuring platform jumping puzzles, boss fights, some simple character dialogue options and a few frustratingly obtuse puzzles. While initially charming, Wuppo loses its sense of fun exploration once you leave the area known as Popo City, roughly 2/3rds of the way into the game. Wuppo’s final segment feels increasingly obtuse as you attempt to solve an increasing number of puzzles which lack detailed dialogue informing you where to go, what to do or even what your objectives are until after the puzzles are complete. As a result, I found myself frequently consulting a walkthrough guide (Wonderful Walkthrough of Wuppo by TemmieNeko) to help me figure out how to finish, what I had initially assumed would be a far less conventional and less obtuse game. 

After watching Wuppo’s previews I had thought I was getting into a sort of slice-of-life, open-world Stardew Valley (except with no farming) side-scroller about a cute thing looking for a new home in a strange city (and maybe dealing with some of the social issues in that city) which might wind up taking a hundred hours or so to play through. Wuppo is actually much shorter (roughly 11 hours) and far more conventional than that, encouraging you to progress through the game in a largely linear fashion, fighting one boss after another before going on the next big area. 

To its credit Wuppo does try to include a few open-world gameplay elements here and there (like getting a job delivering newspapers in the city or doing a few simple fetch quests) but they never end up feeling very deep or even entirely finished. Wuppo does deliver an interesting, often bizarre but still fun, heartfelt story though. It also mentions issues such as racial/historical prejudice and even a little about environmentalism but again these topics are almost never thoroughly explored. Altogether, Wuppo is 2/3rds fun and 1/3rd frustration making it not a truly great game but merely okay. 

+Highly responsive controls which worked well with my keyboard and mouse. Movement controls are handled well with the keyboard and aiming and shooting is handled easily with the mouse.

+Interesting music with some nice music scattered here and there unexpectedly. The Definitive edition gives you 2 soundtracks (located in the game’s steam folder which it installed to) which, when combined give you every song in the entire game.

+Nice sounds. Every single sound has a particular meaning and is useful. The sounds do not become irritating.

+Nice plot with a nice, though pretty “far out there” ending. 

+Platform jumping puzzles never get too frustrating.

+Good satire of what crowded amusement parks are usually like.

+Good satire of what crowded cities are usually like.

+Good satire in general.

+No errors or bugs that I noticed.

+Several difficultly levels increase replay value.

+Lots of side/unnecessary things to do in this game (like go on rides in the amusement park or be on a TV game show) also help increase replay value.

+/-The plot becomes increasingly bizarre and “far out.” It really goes off the deep end eventually when it starts referring to alternate worlds. However the plot points also become increasingly irrelevant.

+/-Should I really have to wait 5 real-world minutes for the Popo City train to arrive?! Though the nearby amusement park was a nice touch.

+/-This game looks like its intended for kids but I don’t think it actually is. At least, it’s definitely not ONLY for kids. 

+/-Lots of text-bubble dialogue, much of it quite cute. Unfortunately, the game gives you no useful or real choices to make in the dialogue which have much of an effect on how the game progresses.

-Some really confusing puzzles which might be too complicated/frustrating for kids especially towards the end of the game. A few areas where you have to jump off the screen and onto a platform on the next screen.

-By the final third of the game (after you leave Popo City) you stop receiving detailed instructions on what to do, where to go or what is needed to solve critical puzzles to advance the plot. You are quite suddenly left to fend for yourself in the deep end of the pool after having had your hand held up to that point (with one exception early in the game). The puzzles also suddenly become much harder to figure out.

-You can blow your character’s money on items to make your character look even cuter (but they don’t actually help you in any way) but you can’t sell them back to shops. The descriptions of some of these items make it sound as though they would actually be useful for your character to have when, in fact, having them makes no actual difference.

-Only one alternate bad ending which you can get only by doing something monumentally stupid while characters urge you not to do it. The game’s main ending (Which comes from defeating the game’s final boss) cannot be changed or altered through your actions or dialogue options up to that point. This drastically decreases replay value.

This game is just pure joy, I think that's the best way that I can describe it. It's goofy, it's weird, it's adorable, and really it's just plain fun. It may not be the best metroidvania I've ever played, but it's certainly one of the most unique. The story, the characters, and the world itself are all incredibly charming and memorable. There are even a series of collectible film strips you can find all over the place that help add to the world building. 

That's not to say that the gameplay is bad either, because it's certainly not. The boss fights are fairly challenging while never being particularly frustrating, and there's quite a variety of things to do besides progressing the plot if you just wander off in some random direction. If you're in the mood for a game with lots of personality that's just a dumb silly good time, this one will probably provide you with exactly what you're looking for.

77852188.review:
My list of games I love -- not just like, not just count as a favorite, but *love* -- is short, but I think this game makes that list. I got this as part of a Humble Bundle, and honestly this was worth the price I paid for the whole bundle.

It's got a cute, appealing graphic design that can still combine with the music to be creepy or whatever mood is needed. The bosses are inventive and sometimes challenging (on easy, admittedly). The storyline is fun, as our protagonist learns (or doesn't learn) to be less of a jerk to others as he explores the world. The worldbuilding is sufficient and fun. The collectibles and minigames and dialogs are fun. It all comes together so enjoyably.

I can tell this was a work of love, with plenty of detail I have yet to see, despite being the sort of player who reads all the dialog and investigates all the crannies. (For one thing, there are still four bosses for me to find . . . and I haven't bought the plot items to find out what they do either . . .)

That said, this is not a game to be sped through, so if you have a pile of fifty unplayed games waiting for your attention you might want to wait on this. The fun for me was immersion in the world, and poking around and exploring and relishing each new discovery. And yes, winning fights with my paint cannon.

this game isn't for me...i understand it's premise but it's just not got that gameplay "hook" I was looking for. it reminds a lot of Zelda in that you have to do a lot of running around talking to people and learning about the people and the world. you can go pretty much anywhere you want and the game feels very open for you to explore and experiment with things. It just lacks direction and the execution of it's ideas are very...unique...just like the art style. 

Unique is probably the best word - This is a niche title for someone whose looking for a nice lil' world to lose themselves in. I don't have the patience for these games anymore but I'm sure someone younger would enjoy it a lot. I know my child self would have loved playing this with my sister back in the day...

So...good for new people to games and the young but if you're a seasoned gamer it might feel a little amateur and "loose" in it's delivery. The controls are pretty unique as are the menu's and user interface. 

It is cool though...much respect to the designer. Definitely replicates that Nintendo feel that Zelda is know for..

6/10

74228097.review:
Wuppo feels a lot like Paper Mario, has a fairly generic (easily grasped, tricky to perfect) battle mechanic, (it was mostly dodging and timing that were tricky for me) cute and unique characters, an equally unique art style, a story with a very silly premise, a world that's fun to explore, and an overall fun and humorous adventure for all ages.
Also there's a surprising amount of lore in this game, most of which is optional, (like choosing to talk to elderly characters who were involved in historical events) but I feel works well to flesh out the world.

Not for people who want a game that takes itself seriously, don't want cutesy characters or themes, or generally silly premises. 
I don't feel it overdoes any of these factors, but still feel it's important to mention if anyone reading particularly dislikes those sort of things.

I give it a solid 8/10, this made me feel really happy to play, and really felt like something I'd play on the Gamecube in my teens. Just carefree, story-driven fun.

73222917.review:
I tried. I did! I saw the reviews, the game looked cute--IS cute--but I can't even finish it.

I figure if I'm 3+ hours in and still not looking forward to playing it, something's wrong here. As I said, the designs are cute, but the game lacks substance. Other than getting kicked out of my apartment for spilling ice cream on the floor and having to flop around through little side quests as I try to find a new place to live, I don't see a plot or a reason to care. There's a lot of world "fluff," meaning the world looks bigger than it actually is (some places are there for the sole purpose of making it look bigger and not adding any challenge or obstacle to the game, such as random empty rooms, large open spaces you have to walk across, so on and so forth).

I feel like you'd only get your money's worth if you went for all or most of the achievements. They're what make you explore everything, try all the pointless mini-games, find all the bosses, so on and so forth, but it's not enough motivation for me when the game just isn't fun. Plot-wise and mechanics-wise.

Add to that the few bugs I've encountered, such as the game lagging when I click on a dialogue option and my Wum literally sitting there, sometimes for an entire minute, with the dialogue option I chose frozen in place and no one doing anything. I have to keep resetting to get it up to speed (that or sit there for an entire minute just so my Wum can say, "Okay!" to someone, which no thank you). And one time I got stuck in a pipe because the game brought me in through the floor and I had to reset.

I just can't look a friend in the eye and legitimately say, "Yes, you should try this game." So I won't to any of you, either. Especially not at its regular buying price.

72945364.review:
Charming platform/sidescroller/RPG with light exploration elements but is let down by a number of minor annoyances that add up.

The main annoyance is the world, it feels lived in and truly like a city, but realism doesn't really equate to fun. There are tonnes of npcs jumping around and moving, making most places feel really cluttered, there are tonnes of vendors and stores selling a lot of stuff, but most of it is fluff or pieces of flavor, which doesn't detract that much but gives you an impression that the city is kind of a waste of time.

This is compounded by the day/night system where you have to wait for certain events and the general pacing of the game. It suffers from JRPG syndrome where the best way forward is just talking to EVERYONE until it becomes clear what to do, which means a LOT of text and although well written, it starts to wear on you. Then the city section of the game has you doing sidequests to build up "credit" in order to improve the city, meaning tonnes of mini quests that pad the already short playtime.

Which is a shame because the game starts out fairly action heavy with motivation to find a new home, then starts to meander in a large world with many little distractions and oddities, becoming a sort of generic JRPG with reams of text and waiting in the effort of "immersion".

The combat is also fairly shallow but entertaining, working as a sidescrolling shooter, but with limited customization and basic dodge/shoot encounters. The main criticism is that the gameplay is good, but there is far too much walking around in cities/populated areas and listening to dialog that brings the pace to a crawl.

It reminds me of Paper Mario but with poor pacing, no combat system and about 4x the NPCS. It's main fault is even though my progress says I've gone quite far, much of that was just milling around the wum house figuring out what to do.

Wow, I can't believe how much I enjoyed this game!

I watched a vod of one of my favorite streamers playing this game, and instantly fell in love with it. He had only played a little of it on stream, and I desperately wanted play and see what happened next in this game, so I bought it. And I am so glad I did. 

TLDR: Get this game if you love fun, immersive games with fabulous characters and a great story!

This game is really adorable, I absolutely love the art style. The music is also way better than it should be. So in terms of aesthetic, this game gets a 10/10.

The story is very compelling. I don't want to spoil anything in this so I will not. But there is a lot of lore, and a lot of depth in  the story. The story is a 10/10 for me.

The gameplay is not difficult to understand. Anyone can start up this game and play it. If you are an experienced "gamer" then this game has a lot of different difficulties to challenge you. The platforming is not hard either, no where near Super Meat Boy levels, so you don't need to worry about raging towards the platforming. The bosses aren't too hard. I would probably give the gameplay an 8/10, very good.

The characters are unbelievably lively. Every single character you interact with feels real and genuine. This game rewards you when you interact with characters, but I wasn't trying to find every character and filmstrip due to a reward, I was doing it because I wanted to, because it was super fun learning about this world and the wums, blussers, fnakkers, and splenkknackers. Characters get a 13/10.

Literally the only thing I would change about this game is for there to be a little epilogue where you can actually be in the world that was described in the credits. And I am well aware of how big of an ask that is. Basically, I wish I could continue playing this game forever!!

Seriously, this game is great!!! Highly recommend!

71600516.review:
This game is pure, uninhibited joy. It put a big dumb smile on my ace and always put me in a good mood. :)

It wasn't without its flaws however. Keep in mind this is an indy game made by two guys.

Pros:
-Really colorful artstyle that's very cute (think Paper Mario)
-Well developped world building which sets up expectations, then defies them in clever ways
-Really big, impressive bosses that often appear out of nowhere and move with gusto
-Puzzles that are pretty easy to figure out but satisfying. Your 8-year old probably could no problem.
-A ton of optional surprises, secrets, side-activities, minigames & bosses along the way.
-Really strange characters/enemies that make you go wtf (as intended)(this game's artist has a peculiar obsession with lips)
-Fast travel unlocked late in the game which lets you find some neat stuff you may have missed or some new things.
-Plenty of items to find, buy, sell, collect and play around with, which will satisfy the collector player.
-Though simple, the world has a lot of lore & history, which can discovered and your knowledge of it can be put to the test in an actually really fun quiz minigame (think Paper Mario x100).
-The game may seem directed only to kids, but there is some surprisingly mature, witty and smart banter.

Cons:
-Waiting. There's a lot of waiting for things, for the sake of immersion I guess? This would be fine if there was an item to speed up time, but there isn't!
-Bosses are quite intimidating the first time around, but aren't all that fun to fight more than once.
-Due to previous point I wasn't interested in the Boss Rush mode.
-Train didn't show up in Popo City. Bug? This was exacerbated by the waiting.
-The rides in theme park were VERY underwhelming. Again, exacerbated by waiting in line (yes, you literally wait in line for a while for them to finish the ride).
-Some important secrets are a little too obscure to figure out, to the point I had to seek info online. This is true for one strong powerup in particular.
-There is a TON of items with no use apart from being esthetic. Especially the hats. This is almost a crime. There so many times I talked to someone with a hat (talking to an NPC with a disguise) but got no reaction. Not to mention the cost of said hat. Just a waste. Now, there are SOME reactions (namely those required for the main story), but this should have been much more developped.
-Non-boss enemies are never more than an inconvenience or an annoyance, or ally with you. Even on hard combat is never challenging.

Bottom-line:
I think this game is great for anyone, regardless of age. It's very impressive for a two-man team to have built such a neat and creative world.
If you're a fan of Paper Mario, you'll probably love this, too.
I feel like all the cons I mentioned could have been remedied. Perhaps they were pressed by time before release?
Highly Recommended.

71106720.review:
Wuppo: A Cute, Bite-Sized Adventure

Soundtrack……………………………………………………………………….…⭐⭐⭐/☆☆ (3.5/5)
- This game’s soundtrack is good. Some of the songs are better than others, especially when comparing some of the area themes. 
Graphics………………......……………………………………..............................⭐⭐⭐/☆☆ (3/5)
- The game has a cute, fun artstyle overall. All the colors really just breathe “fun” and “happy” all around. I couldn’t actually experience the graphics at their prime though; in order for this game to run on my potato computer was to turn on potato graphics (makes perfect sense.)
Atmosphere/Mood…………………………………………………………………..⭐⭐⭐⭐/☆ (4/5)
- The game is very good at making you feel small and insignificant, yet still manages to make the world fun and full of curiosity. 
Gameplay……………………………………………………………………………..⭐⭐⭐/☆☆ (3/5)
- Gameplay is alright, though it feels like it has too much walking around. Some of the bosses are pretty fun and actually present a unique idea, which is nice to see in smaller titles. The NPCs are alright. Their dialogue isn’t anything special. 
Potential Time Investment…………………………………………………………....⭐/☆☆☆☆ (1/5)
- There isn’t actually a whole lot to explore in this game, and it offers little replay value besides achievement hunting, which not everyone enjoys. 
Price………………………………………………………………………………….....⭐/☆☆☆☆ (1/5)
- The price for this game is simply too high. $14.99 for only around 25 hours of content kind of sucks. However, the sale price of only $1.49 is a pretty fine purchase.
Lacking of Bugs……………………………………………………………………⭐⭐⭐⭐/☆ (4.5/5)
- I have not actually encountered a single bug during the entire time I’ve played, which is a great comment for any game regardless of its size. 
Overall Star Verdict*...……………………………………………………………🌟🌟🌟/☆☆ (20/35)
- Overall the game is pretty average. It doesn’t have a lot that makes it stand out, but it's a fun experience nonetheless. 

*Overall Star Verdict is calculated by finding the mean of the seven different categories; that is, adding them all up and dividing them by the amount (7) to calculate the Verdict. Generally, the initial Verdict will be rounded up for the final one.

Wuppo is about a tiny journey of a little creature known as a Wum who got kicked out of his apartment for spilling ice cream throughout the hallway. Clearly, the game isn’t very serious. Instead, it’s a fun, cute yet utterly short and puzzle filled adventure. It’s a bit like Cuphead in the sense that it has a high emphasis on boss fights, minus the extreme difficulty. The game is almost entirely linear, with little choice in how the story progresses. Even if you don’t do certain events you don’t miss out on much. Still, you’ll get around 20 or 25 hours out of this game for your first playthrough, depending on your competency in puzzle solving. There are other difficulty options for playthroughs, but again there is little reason to replay the entire game again on a higher setting. At that point everything has been seen and nothing new will really come from it. I suppose if you enjoy achievement hunting then you might spend a lot more time into this game. 

There’s kind of a second gamemode in Wuppo called “Boss Rush.” As the name suggests, you have to beat all the bosses in one life and get very few items along the way. This again has its own difficulty settings, and they are considerably harder than the default game just due to how little healing you can get. It’s a lot of trial and error to try and do it right. Again, this might be perfect for achievement hunters. 

This game does have a co-op feature. I have not explored this at all, but I figured I should put it here since it does seem like a fun game to play with another person. 

Overall Wuppo is a fun journey that has very little replayability and certainly isn’t worth the cost. If it’s on it’s sale price of $1.49 then it’s fine, ‘cause what do you have to lose at that point?

tl;dr/ don't care about my fan boy ramblings 9/10! 
Recommend definitely for fans of sidescrolling shoot and indie games. And even if not give it a try even if sidescroilling shooters aren't quite your favorite thing. As I am sure you can find something cool to take away from this unique quirky gem. 

 Okay so here we go, this game is going to be something you DEFINITELY want to play as long as you like side scrolling cursor shooters. And if you don't I would still recommend it if you are open to that game type because Wuppo all be it a very comedic game and doesn't take itself serious it is still such a new experience. There are so many facets to the gameplay beyond just a sidescrolling shooter. It honestly surprised me with it's nuances, details, and little curve balls it throws at you through the story. It is a fun and worthwhile experience, and granted I feel I might talking it up too much right now cause really it is an indie game. But I personally love indie games and this thrilled my socks right off my feet. And those are definitely my favorite things that have really gotten my attention so far.

 The Base story isn't much really but the adventure it takes you on is where it really shines. The world feels so lush, active, and alive despite the fact that it's all 2D. The characters are fun and even at times you will find yourself kind of attached to some of them. And the places the adventure goes will really surprise you if you are used to expectable linear stories. Granted this game is linear as well but it feels different in the places it takes you places that I personally didn't quite expect. And the sarcastic goofy atmosphere just adds to it. Even only 5 hours in I am so enthused on this game and have yet to finish it even. And the combat is fun and dynamic depending on how you play and what you use. 

OVERALL if you want a game that can give you a a light enjoyable experience and throw you some curve balls. Even give you a break from a lot of the same old same old of game progression with a good difficulty incline and a fun story. Then definitely dig right in ya hungry soul. And even if you aren't a fan of the genre I still say give it a try if you want something different to really refresh your palette cause I am sure there is something you can enjoy and take from this game. 

The score I would give it is an absolute 9/10.

68022372.review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Knowing your own limitations and being able to be creative within those bounds is half the challenge of game design, and [i]Wuppo[/i] is a masterpiece in demonstrating that restraint. The quaint art style, the lovable characters, and the surprisingly deep world all come together to make [i]Wuppo[/i] a sleeper-hit.

[h1]Of Bluss & Wum[/h1]
The crowning achievement of [i]Wuppo[/i], is the game's ability to organically let the player discover the world. And what a world there is to discover! For a game with an incredibly small "map" to physically explore, [i]Wuppo[/i] instead packs all of the detail into the NPCs the player interacts with. NPCs aren't just filler, they have emotions, goals, and story-lines of their own. The genius of [i]Wuppo[/i] is that the game gives players a reason to discover this world: to discover [b]Happiness[/b]. By making NPCs happy, your Wum's heart also grows and in-turn makes you hardier. This sort of incentive for the players to interact and [b]really[/b] have a dialogue with the NPCs never feels shoehorned in and is a great example of the organic world-building I mentioned earlier.

Looking past what's in the game, it's also good to note how much is achieved with the resources given. [i]Wuppo[/i] isn't an expansive game but there's no lack of things happening. It doesn't try to put in a ton of unnecessary weapons and crafting and collectibles to beef up the content cause the game knows what it has is good enough. The first weapon you're given, the Gumgumgun, is pretty much the only weapon you'll use throughout the game; players can buy very minimal upgrades to attach to their Gumgumgun, but that's really the extent of the crafting system; and the only collectible in the game, [b]Filmstrips[/b], aren't just shiny doodads, but are utilitarian in that they provide a lot of narrative. [i]Wuppo[/i] doesn't try to impress by delivery a ton of half-baked ideas, but instead keeps what it serves lean, but well-polished.

[h1]Breakdown[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[olist]
    [*][b]Squigglenautic:[/b] The art and music of the game never overshadows the gameplay, but complements it perfectly. Certain aesthetics of the game does feel strange, but the purposefully janky graphics never feels like a negative.
    [*][b]Positive Reinforcement:[/b] One of the most important ways we see [i]Wuppo[/i] reward exploration is that save points are literally everywhere. You're rewarded with going outside the lines and searching the nooks and crannies, but if you make a mistake, you can reset without punishment or significant loss of progress.
[/olist]
[b]Cons[/b]
[olist]
    [*][b]Real-Time Travel:[/b] This is ultimately a minor quibble, but having to wait for the trains and trams in real-time was a tiny bit annoying.
    [*][b]I'm Just a Poor Boy:[/b] The currency in the game, [b]Smurt[/b] is a bit hard to come by. While it's understandable to limit the amount you get before you go to Popocity (so players don't just buy a ticket and bypass exploring the Wumhouse), after you reach Popocity, it's really a bit of an unnecessary slog to farm for Smurt afterwards.
[/olist]

[b]Score:[/b] 9/10
