64780836.review:
It almost pains me to give this game a negative review - it was clearly made with a lot of heart and there is a huge amount of charm in the visuals, sounds and music. As a game, though, it feels like a lot of loose ends that all lead somewhere else but none of them are quite finished.

One issue lies in the open-ended design of the game; at any given moment, there is a plethora of stuff you can do and several places you can go to. There is a "main quest" of sorts, but it is not really definitive and as such the game feels a little bit directionless. You can gather filmstrips and watch them for money, interact with other tribes and listen to some funny dialogue, all with the end goal of finding a new home in the big city. You are essentially solving a bunch of side quests and helping people with that goal in mind, as well as increasing your happiness (health). 

It is all well and good, but then there are problems. There is a ton of stuff you can buy, all of which seems to enable small side quests or different dialogue or upgrade your weapons, but there are not enough ways to earn money; I have rarely seen a game with currency this sparse, and I was watching film clips and solving quests as much as I could. There are a lot of bosses, but none of them feel very creative in their mechanics and some are downright cheap or annoying. The fighting mechanics in this game are also a bit clunky (you have different guns you can aim and shoot) and the difficulties are just balanced by making the enemies do tons of damage the higher you go, killing you in three to four hits on the highest difficulty on bosses that can take over 5 minutes to defeat. The game also forces you to wait up to 5 minutes periodically for trains or other in game events.

It is a charming and witty game, but the *game* part just felt very disjointed to me. Once I arrived in the PoPo City and got essentially 5 different tasks to help people out, none of which were explained very well (how do I get newspapers to give to people? Where do I have to go to solve the factory puzzle?) I kind of gave up. Whenever the game gives you a task, you are expected to figure out how it works - which sometimes works, and sometimes it doesnt. I have no problem with such games (Dark Souls is a good example of a directionless game done right), but the weak mechanics and flimsy platforming as well as the unbalanced difficulty and huge lack of direction in both design and gameplay turned me off in the end.

Long story short, it is a charming and witty game with an interesting and cool world to dive into for a little bit - that is definitely the huge strength of the game. Sadly, the actual active *game* part lacks direction and solidity, and was just not a lot of fun to me. I would still get it on sale, if only to experience some of the charming dialogue in this whimsical world - maybe it will be for you!

64474529.review:
One of the happiest gaming experiences for me in a long time, Wuppo obviously has been created with passion and an eye for detail. It's a cute story about a lazy potato, who clearly has yet to learn the meaning of responsibility.
The game has great dialogue, a strong backstory and lots of hidden pieces of lore and secret items, which invite to explore a beautifully designed open world. Wuppo has a level of depth I didn't expect, with a vivid world, that is influenced by your progression through the game.

The story took me around 8 hours to complete on normal while spending reasonable time on secrets.
If I had kids, I would love to play Wuppo in co-op with them, though I'd recommend this game to any age group.

63470727.review: So this actually ended up being on of my more favorite games I've played in a long time. The game itself is not all that large, but the way it was developed around knowing the limitations is what is most impressive. There is an almost open world feel to the map, with multiple currencies, items, choices, and places to go for various reasons (some are not even necessary for game completion). The way there was so much extra dialogue and so many extra choices (that ultimately still lead to the same conclusion but just offered a different path to get there) were nice. Those really made the game feel much bigger than it actually was. The story was good as well. It concluded a bit weak in my opinion at the very end, almost like the developers wanted to wrap things up quickly, but that is such a small part of it that it didn't really do any harm, just a little sad. The "Overwhelmingly Positive" amount of reviews this title has is 100% earned here for sure.

60625134.review:
This game is a true hidden gem. Emphasis on "hidden" because even though it's got "overwhelmingly positive" reviews, I see and hear almost no one talk about. I stumbled upon it by complete accident while browsing metroidvania games. People say that this is is "two man passion project", and seeing the amount of work and creativity that was put into this game, I can totally get behind that.

The gameplay is actually pretty simple. You control a little marshmellow spider guy called a "Wum" and you basically platform around, solve puzzles, and occasionally fight stuff. Like most metroidvanias, exploration is very rewarding, with lots of secrets, items, and little bonuses stuffed into every nook and cranny. But unlike most metroidvanias, backtracking won't be something you'll find yourself doing a whole lot. As the story progresses, you'll be traveling from location to location, constantly moving forward. You do get new abilities in the form of new items to let you progress, but while they can sometimes help you explore areas that were previously blocked off, it's by no means a requirement. It's mainly again for advancing the story and moving forward. I don't see this as a bad thing, in fact, considering that fast travel is only available SUPER late in the game, it was a smart decision to encourage exploration without making a requirement. As for the controls, they feel smooth and responsive, just the way I like it. It may take you a bit to get used to the control scheme, but that's hardly a complaint. This game is pretty easy overall, the main challenge comes from the bosses and figuring out what to do. I occasionally found myself overthinking a puzzle during my playthrough, only to realize the very simple and honestly somewhat obvious solution. The game can have those "What am I supposed to do now?" moments, but try not to overthink them, as hints on what to do are plentiful and will point in the right direction. The bosses on the other hand are hard because of their hard to dodge attack patterns. There aren't many moments where the boss will present itself to be hit, meaning you have to blast away at them while simultaneously dodging their attacks. Almost like a bullet hell when you think about it. But like the core gameplay, they're simple, and it's not too hard to figure out what attacks do what before you get it down. You may get your little wum butt kicked again and again, but it's all about memorizing what they do and finding an ideal time to open fire. And if you want some more challenging battles, there's a boss rush available after beating the game.

But gameplay aside, the REAL hero here is the presentation. This game literally feels like a child's art piece come to life. The way everything is drawn with this adorable childish style just oozes with charm. Everything about this game is super adorable, from the silly looking characters, to the cartoonish sound effects, I mean you literally shoot CANDY as your primary attack. Everything feels like the imagination of a 5 year-old, and to my surprise, it works, and I love it. The story matches that tone to a T. Basically, a bunch of creatures called Fnakkers wanted to rule the world, but together with the Blussers and Splenkhakkers, the clever Wums pushed them into a sinkhole. You play as a Wum who got kicked out of a hotel for spilling ice cream and now you need a new home. It's simple and charming, but I was really surprised by the how the actually expanded upon these ideas further. There's actually some legitimately interesting depth and lore to this game, and that surprised me! But don't worry folks, there's no super dark twist or edgy villains or anything, the game maintains that quirky whimsical charm the whole the through, it even gets straight bizarre too! I adore the presentation, and I feel like it alone makes it worth your time.

Now normally, this is where I'd put my complaints about this game, but I'm in a weird spot. See, when I played, my main issue was how you can only hold one item at a time, having to flip through a menu everytime you wanted to switch, but since then, the devs have actually added a quick select to fix that problem. So yeah, no complaints here!

Overall 10/10 game, I love it to pieces. I'd love to see a sequel of some sort, or at the very least, see more from these two devs

59938903.review:
[h1] Wuppo - Definitive Edition [/h1] 

[b] A Charming, Funny, Above Average Adventure Game [/b]

[b] Wuppo - Definitive Edition [/b] is a unique, colorful, and cute little game. It has many mechanics within it, ranging from light RPG systems to a surprisingly detailed world, and even includes a decent amount of fighting and some platforming. I personally got a little tired of it, but it doesn't mean that the title was bad by any means.

The game is very open in terms of its story, while there are generally objectives to complete within this title, you are able to travel around the semi-open world and complete various activities and meet different creatures. I found the lack of direction sometimes to be frustrating, since it would only say to "find x item" or "complete y objective", but I assume it is because some goals can be accomplished in different ways. This freedom is nice for an indie game that I assumed would be a basic platformer, but it is pretty rich in content. 

The world is definitely larger than I expected in this title, with an entire city to explore, an well-sized apartment complex, and multiple types of areas ranging from a jungle, to an underground tunnel, to a chain of islands. There are a LOT of items in this game, and most seem cosmetic, but the options are there for those who want to grind out money to try different outfits/items out. I thought the opening section was fun, with a good platforming sequence and a couple of cool boss battles, but the middle stretch of the game is where I got bored personally. I didn't like the fact that multiple odd jobs would have to be completed in order to progress the story, and it dragged the gameplay to a screeching halt. This was disappointing because I felt the game had a cool style to it, but it runs into the issue of trying to do too much without fleshing any one thing out.

[b] Wuppo - Definitive Edition [/b] was an interesting game to try out. While I didn't get a chance to fully complete it, I found it to be an interesting experience nonetheless. The game has a boatload of systems, yet doesn't flesh out any one particular aspect out very well. If it cut a few areas and streamlined the objectives needed to be completed, I feel I would have enjoyed it more than I did, but to each there own. I will still [b] Recommend [/b] this game, as it provides enough diversity and uniqueness to its gameplay, despite it not hitting the right notes for me. Give this title a try, and you might end up finding your own personal hidden gem!

[h2] Final Verdict: 6/10 (Above Average) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37542043-ADHD-Reviews/

56459331.review: A wonderfully charming game, [i]Wuppo[/i] is a 2D platform/adventure ('Metroidvania', perhaps?) game set in a world inhabited by a number of Kirby-like 'blob' creatures; in particular the game follows an exiled 'wum' in the search for a new home. As the game progresses, it does a great job of laying out its strange world, with an impressive amount of background lore to discover and the initially slightly 'amateur'-feeling low-res graphics come to feel very fitting, helping to heighten the world's strangeness. There's a enjoyable variety in the tasks that you'll need to take on to progress, from the mainstay of twin-stick shooting combat through to distributing newspapers and fishing - the game does a lot with quite a limited set of tools. To raise just one niggle, if you want to seek out 100% completion/collection after beating the main game, this can get a bit tedious in one respect, as you'll need to earn a decent chunk of money for a few things and these's no particularly quick and easy way of doing so. Besides this, though, there's a nice in-game clue system to help you towards full completion, which helps to balance out the potential 'grindy' element.

55783538.review:
Very fun and very cute game that reminds me of a lot of childhood favourites. Story-wise, I'd say it's pretty similar to a Paper Mario game, with a unique world, fun dialogue, and interesting and silly NPCs. I enjoyed slowly learning about this weird little world with its weird little inhabitants; there's lots to look around at and explore, and tons of tidbits of information lying around (mainly in the form of "filmstrips", a collectable you'll find in various places that contain a mini slideshow of sorts)

Gameplay-wise, it's pretty simplistic and kind of makes me think of those old web browser flash games. Very simple controls and combat, you run, jump, and fire your weapon (which has optional upgrades and variations), and little much else besides using items to advance the story or solve small puzzles. Personally, I'm okay with this. I enjoy simple games like this every now and then, especially ones that are just charming and fun for the sake of being fun. The only thing I'm a little disappointed with are the bosses, which are waaay to easy and can all be easily beaten by continuously firing at them and bringing a good supply of healing items.

Overall, I really enjoyed this little game! I definitely recommend it to anyone who's into what I described above, but I don't think it'd be very enjoyable for any hardcore gamer that dislikes simplicity. Of course, it's not very expensive so I still recommend giving it a shot anyway! the worst possible outcome is that you spend some time looking around this cute, charming little world and decide it isn't for you

53980508.review:
Wuppo is one of those games where you see the Overwhelmingly Positive track record, and it makes you scratch your head as to why you've never heard of it, or what could be so enthralling in a game about a little puffball who wears a bunch of hats that give him different abilities and this is starting to sound like a Kirby game the further I go with this. Yes, Kirby is one of my favorite characters ever, mind your own business.

I picked it up on sale along with a handful of other cheap games that piqued my interest, and Wuppo stands out as one of the most charming games I've played.

Wuppo is like if a game developer was challenged to create a full game using a Game Jam prompt, and the staff consisted of 13 year-old Timmy from next door on Art Direction, that one class-clown theater kid from high school English Lit as the writing staff, and the two college students in charge of coding and music that somehow keep it all in line.

And it works fantastically.

In spite of only being about two hours deep - apparently that's about a fifth of the game's entire playtime (non-100%) - the game swept me up in its passively sarcastic tone and straightforward plot. It's childish simplicity done right, where instead of feeling juvenile, it feels lighthearted and silly. It's tongue-in-cheek in an aggressively playful way that practically forces you to un-bunch your grumpy-pants and lighten up, whether you want to or not. Exploring the world is satisfying thanks to the tight controls that allow for fun platforming while offering some light puzzle-solving. The whole thing has a very "flash game" feel to it, but reaps the benefits of a talented team that built it with dedication and care, working by the mantra "don't take it too seriously." Hard/Insane mode adds a fun layer of challenge for those looking to get a bit more bang for their buck and really test themselves.

If you're in the market for a charming, casual Metroidvania title that you can beat in a weekend, you can't do much better than Wuppo.

53030030.review:
[h1]All For Wum, Wum For All[/h1]

[b]Wuppo = Knytt + Mr. Saturn + Ice Cream[/b]

This is definitely one of the most charming games you're going to stumble across, but don't let the low-fi pastel graphics fool you.  Wuppo has enough under the hood to scratch your platformer/exploration itch.

This game really brings to mind oldskool indie platformer classics like Knytt or Seiklus.  In fact, if you like either of those titles, it's probably a given that you'lve love Wuppo.  It helps that the game has the great advantage of also NOT feeling like a platformer in the sense that it feels more like a fully-realized world that you incidentally platform your way through.

It also has light Metroidvania and RPG aspects, as you definitely need to have certain items to proceed through certain areas, and there can be frequent backtracking to previously inaccessible areas.  You also have a weapon that you can improve and modify, which adds a little bit of that RPG grind feel to your progress.

Boss fights can sometimes be challenging, and there are a number of puzzles, but the real way in which Wuppo shines is simply observing/taking part in the living world that all these adorable little critters live in.  It is somewhat reminiscent of Mr. Saturn from Earthbound, not only in how the Wums look, but also how zany their society operates.

[i]Become Wum of Many if...[/i]

[list]
[*] You want an interactive, exploration-focused experience in a convincing world.
[*] You want a platformer that's a little more laid back and off the beaten path.
[*] You are looking for a game that is as cute as it is clever.
[/list]

[i]You're not the Wum if...[/i]

[list]
[*] You are looking for a very mechanics-focused platformer.
[*] You need hardcore difficulty.
[*] You need lots of action and combat.
[/list]

[u]The Bottom Line[/u]

Wuppo is an overlooked titan of exploration-platformers.  Unlike other, similar indie platformers, Wuppo goes the extra mile in terms of making you feel like a true, weird little world is happening all around you, and it also helps that there is plenty of clever writing and dialogue that is every bit as charming as the visual presentation.

If you have the patience for a somewhat leisurely-paced, exploration-focused metroidvania-lite experience, you really would be missing the train (it has that too!) by not giving Wuppo a try.

52734649.review:
[h1] Probably as cute as it sounds	[/h1]

Somewhere between marshmallow and dust bunny, is a wum, one of the three or so races found in this quaint world. After being kicked out of his residence we get to follow him on his journey of jumping, shooting gumballs, making friends, and finding happiness. It may come off as saccharin on paper, but is implemented quite well. Throughout the game your HP (happiness points ) can be increased by doing things like riding a roller coaster, helping people , making friends, learning something new, etc. It’s a neat mechanic and does a great job showing heroes growth. There are many optional things to do just for the sake of doing them: the aforementioned rollercoaster costs many you have to earn on your own time, and then you have to queue up like any other citizen, the game will not let you on the ride if you cut in line. It’s a neat way to tie the narrative’s idea of character growth through the mechanics.

 What began as a selfish wum who was so consumed by TV he consumed it, ends with a wum exploring relationships and maturing. One of the notable fights includes a boss’s confused and sad reactions that reminded me of Earthbound. It’s a running theme that a lot of the beings in the game, enemy or not, are just misunderstood.  Such as a pet whose owner didn't teach him better. The racism and prejudice in Wuppos’ world is treated in a light hearted manner, but it’s still a major schism in the game. 

It’s not too long but there are plenty of secrets and sidequests. It’s a rich world with lots of lore. What could be silly world with little context is actually fleshed out quite well, mostly through collectible film reels, or through talking with characters. The epilogue ties everything up nicely- and a sequel would be more than welcome. 

The whimsical style and bright colors hold a rich heart warming game.

*** update, they have made the game even better with a number of changes including co-op. Buy it now.

51122542.review:
At its core, Wuppo is a charming game about exploring a strange world. It has a very unique MSPaint-like cutesy art-style. Most of all - it has character. Neither the story nor its heroes feel copy-pasted from the checklist of video game clichés, as it is often the case. Even names sound like they come from an original exotic language that is meant to twist your tongue in funny ways. It all starts with a lazy icecream-loving creature called Wum being thrown out of its house for being messy and one thing leads to another in organic fashion. I haven't finished the game yet but the dreaded save-the-world cliché has yet to rear it's ugly head. Instead we follow our Wum on a journey of self-discovery and exploration, full of humour and wit. And while it all sounds very childish on paper, and indeed what I've seen of the game has all been very kid-friendly, the story is sprinkled with light socio-political metaphors that add a deeper layer underneath the surface, and the design of the world is so creative that it never stops filling you with wonder.

As far as the gameplay goes it's a metroidvania where you point your mouse where you want to shoot (I don't play with controllers). However, it has more emphasis on exploration, dialogue and even inventory use, like an adventure game, so it's really a mix of genres. It does have its share of fun and bizarre bosses that can take a few tries if you crank up the difficulty like I did. 

Which brings me to two negative points I have: the difficulty setting seems to be tied to game speed. So if you play at lower difficulties your game will get unbearably slow. It should have been kept as a separate setting in my opinion. Also, the game displays a comic-book style effect each time you or something else gets hit - these can obscure the area so much that it gets hard to see where what is, especially if you add a lot of similar looking characters. Sometimes it's also unclear what can be jumped on and what is just background, a problem haunting many platformers.

None of these problems sour the experience too much as the game has a strong core and most of all, it has soul. Unique, quirky, interesting - it embodies everything I love about indie games. #loveindies

50145381.review:
[h1] The Metroidvania Review[/h1]
 [url= https://metroidvaniareview.com/2019/04/15/wuppo/] Scored Summary[/url] |  |                          [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/30503887/] Subscribe to our Curator	[/url]

 [b]How Metroidvania is it?[/b]
Low Fit –  [i]Wuppo[/i] is a lot less about exploration and more about adventure game style puzzle solving. It’s sort of like if [i]Monkey Island[/i] ate a twin stick shooter platformer. 
 
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/MetroidvaniaReview/discussions/1/1744480967004628507/] Want to hear a different opinion, or want to share your own review? Check out our Forum here.[/url]

[h1]Full Review[/h1]
[i]Wuppo[/i] is a strange mix of [i]Paper Mario[/i],  a twin stick shooter platformer, and an adventure game. Something about this mix made people think “Metroidvania” but overall to me it feels like [i]Monkey Island 3[/i] for structural reasons I’ll talk about a little later on. I think if you’re looking for a Metroidvania style experience, [i]Wuppo[/i] has flavors of it, but the primary focus is on quirky characters and adventure game style puzzles, and for what it is it’s a ton of fun. 

The entire premise of the game is that your fat Wum is a slob and gets kicked out of his halfway house thus kicking off his (her?) hijinx filled adventure where he haphazardly saves the universe. All of your interaction with NPCs is done with the kind of flair that you would see in a Nintendo game. Every character has a personality quirk that makes them humorous because they’re larger than life, but they’re also grounded in a reality that makes them feel almost real. Your character is a “Wum”, a species of armless Kirby creatures with tiny bug legs, and he reacts to conversation with amusing facial expressions, giving interactions a delightful energy. The game sort of forces you to learn about the different species in the world – there are at least eight that you interact with – but in spite of it being something of an exposition dump it does it in such an entertaining way that I didn’t mind it.

In fact, that world building is something that [i]Wuppo[/i] strangely does very well. In spite of being a surreal mishmash of both cringe and curiosity, it’s all constructed in a way that made me almost believe it was real place. From an escapist standpoint, [i]Wuppo[/i] is a world that welcomes you in and quietly entices you away from whatever worldly cares you have in real life. The overarching story is a product of weirdness, but perhaps as you play you’ll start to care about the individual characters in the game – or at least – you’ll care about preserving its world as much as possible. A lot of the game’s content is completely optional – only opening up more and new interesting things about its history and characters rather than providing any tangible in-game benefit. But interacting with all of those elements is rewarding in itself, firmly establishing that this is a game less about gameplay and more about its world.

In that vein, puzzle solutions are less rigid than many adventure games. In two of the four major sections of the game, your primary goal isn’t to just get from point A to point B, but rather you’re given an objective that has multiple solutions for accomplishing. This lack of rigidity sets it apart from other adventure games – so while you have several items to brush against things, in many cases they don’t act as “keys” gating your progress as much as they [i]feel[/i] like logical solutions the problem. Not that there aren’t [i]any[/i] key-like puzzle solutions, but the method of getting the key is often open and up to the player on how they want to obtain it. This is all ingenious game design helps to keep the game to that high level of immersion, but it also opens the game up to players that don’t necessarily like the 90s style of adventure game. 

Of course, the more casual 90s adventure gamers would also potentially have some difficulty with [i]Wuppo’s[/i] combat. I played the game on hard mode, but even on the normal difficulty I can only imagine some of the game’s bosses giving less action game oriented players some trouble. There aren’t a ton of “regular” enemies throughout the game world – the ones that are there go down pretty easily save a few annoying fish monsters. The real challenge comes from the 17 bosses. Wuppo is a twin-stick shooter, meaning you’ll be jumping and shooting using your shoulder buttons and controlling your movement and aiming with the analog sticks – if you’re playing with a controller. In twin-stick fashion this means most bosses are a balance of bullet-hell-esque barrages and while continually applying damage to weakpoints as you move. From the boss pattern to your Wum’s controls, everything feels just a little loose, meaning it took me a few tries to get used to new boss patterns before everything clicked. This isn’t necessarily bad, especially since every boss has a checkpoint just prior to facing them, but it’s perhaps not exactly the industry’s best when it comes to combat. But like everything in [i]Wuppo[/i], encounters are more than just a mechanical challenge, there is also a high level of entertainment coming from who and what you’re fighting at any given time. Overall I’d rate the combat as above average. 

As far as [i]Wuppo’s[/i]  “Metroidvania-ness” goes I mentioned previously that it reminds me more of [i]Monkey Island 3[/i] than it does [i]Super Metroid[/i] or [i]Castlevania[/i]. While you can technically go back to any old area as new areas are opened up, you’re given little incentive to do so. Each area plays like a chapter, and once you accomplish the primary goal you move on. There isn’t ever any feeling that you’re exploring to find power-ups to progress, but rather you’re exploring to find information. Because of that I think there might be some crossover in interest for fans of [i]La-Mulana[/i], just with less Metroidvania factor and the combat isn’t quite as difficult. Because of the previously mentioned fluidity of the puzzle design, you’re also not solving riddles in the same way as [i]La-Mulana[/i] – most of the time. There are a few that do require you to know about the game’s world to progress, but they aren’t nearly as prevalent, and if you’re paying attention to the game’s NPC interactions they’re not particularly difficult. 

The primary draw of [i]Wuppo[/i] is its quirky characters, its entertaining method of storytelling, and the overall immersion that its world provides. It has just enough challenge to it to make it more than just an escapist fantasy, but escapism is definitely its main strength. If you’re looking for a break from every day life, and just want a fun and inviting video game world to stay in for a while, [i]Wuppo[/i] is practically unparalled within the confines of its limitations as an indie title. 

4 out of 5

The overarching plot is pretty basic and the last act kind of comes out of nowhere, but this is made up for by the worldbuilding - the world of Wuppo is interesting and there is quite a lot one can learn about it. The mood of the game is really laid back with a good dose of humor.

Only a few minor flaws stood out to me during my playthrough - the aforementioned last act, relatively clunky inventory considering how much item juggling you'll have to do and the fact that an ingame train is on a relatively long realtime schedule (fortunately, you technically only need to use it once).

Overall, I have really enjoyed my time with Wuppo and it is an easy recommendation if you're looking for a relaxed gaming experience. If you end up liking it and find yourself wanting more, I would also like to recommend an oldschool freeware classic called "An Untitled Story" - there are many similarities between them and I would not at all be surprised to learn that it served as an inspiration for Wuppo.

50080543.review:
Wuppo is a puzzle-platformer in which you explore a whimsical and lively world inhabited by four multi-legged, friendly, round-ish shaped races - Wums, Blussers, Splenhakkers and Fnakkers. What starts as a quest to go back home, turns into a engaging story about friendship, politics and meaning of life (with a dash of saving the world thrown in). 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

I feel like the time spent in the game is split between three main elements pretty evenly. Those would be fighting with your trusty Gumgumgun, jumping around and solving puzzles and talking to other creatures.

The boss fights were well-made, I played on normal difficulty and they were challenging enough to make me sweat a little, but not too hard to make me feel frustrated. Each fight was also pretty different from another, regarding the boss mechanics. I'd often die on the first attempt, just to understand the boss' move pattern and breeze through it the next try.

If I had to point out one thing that was constantly bugging me while playing, it would definitely be the inventory management. As you progress through the game, you get more and more items and even through you can set up hotkeys, if you're playing with a controller, there's just not enough buttons to have all the useful items easily accessible, which means you'll be browsing your inventory pretty often. This wouldn't be that much of an issue, however, Wuppo doesn't feature active pause. So, if you're in a boss battle and don't have any healing items bound to a hotkey, you will most likely die. It's not that bad on the normal difficulty, as I didn't find myself using healing items too often anyway, but I feel it might be a huge annoyance when playing on the harder modes.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

The game was made by only two people and it shows. I mean, don't get me wrong, I actually think it looks pretty great, as the rather crude but childish style actually fits the whole game perfectly. However, you might notice that some elements, e.g. the purple tubes in Popo City can be a bit of an eye-sore. Despite that, I do love how the game looks. 

It's often a case with Indie games that even though they look good-ish on the first look, the more you play, the more boring the scenery becomes, you just notice the copy pasting of assets and plain, empty textures covering most of the screen. This is definitely NOT a case with Wuppo. I feel like the devs have spent A LOT of time creating the world, there's a lot of work put into every level. Be it some weird plants in the background, mysterious runes carved into rocks or even some moss in long abandoned ruins. Every part of the world is refreshing in it's own way and I loved exploring them.

One more thing that deserves praise, especially for an indie game like that is the liveliness of the portrayed world. The locations feel really alive. The city is full of Wums rushing somewhere in hurry or just working on something. Creatures are queueing to the Wondersplenk attractions or interacting with each other. Many AAA open-world games could learn a thing or two from Wuppo when it comes to adding a 'beating heart' to the world.

[h1] Sound & Music [/h1]

The music in Wuppo is perfectly made. I felt like every piece was actually carefully chosen for the level I was in. Wumhouse music was really warm and sort of melancholic. The dark passages and ruins had more mysterious and weird soundtracks. The city's music was work-inspiring and fitting the general rush everyone was in perfectly. It's often a bit goofy sounding, which also fits the general theme of the game. The combination of the graphics, sound design and story really reminded me of the time long ago when I played The Neverhood. It just sparked the same warm and melancholic feelings in me and I think it's great that games can still do that.

[h1] Plot and Character Design [/h1]

The story of Wuppo starts rather silly, but develops nicely. It's nothing too original, it's easy to predict how most of the events will unfold. But it's still solid and with a dash of humour added, I was happy to play through it and even watched most of the filmstripes just for the fun of it.

The dialogues can be really brilliantly written. I think I talked to all of the NPCs and always went through all possible options. There's a lot of information hidden there, as well as, jokes or some general life wisdom.

The life wisdom, which actually deserves a paragraph of its own. I think the story is merely a pretext to talk and think about real life and it's problems. It may not be obvious immediately, but the game touches upon a lot of real life topics. For example, the four main races present different approaches to life, or types of people. Wums are more outgoing, Blussers are the introverts, Splenhakkers like building and constructing and Fnakkers seem to be centered mostly on the physical development. But even within one race, like Wums, there are differences. Wums in the Wumhouse like their lazy, relaxed life, while the Wums in Popo city are focused only on work. There's also the focus on making friends, which yet again reminded me of The Neverhood. And let's not forget about the stereotypes and how they're often misleading and disrupt our communication attempts.

All in all, I think there're a lot of topics regarding real life and its meaning embedded into Wuppo. It's not too much 'in your face' though, it doesn't really push any agendas on the player. It mostly just presents how different people have different priorities in their lives and how we should respect that.

[h1] Overall [/h1]

To sum up, I thoroughly enjoyed playing Wuppo. If you feel like setting out on a mystical, but a tad goofy journey through life with boss fights and some puzzles, this is a game for you. Relax and just hop into this slightly crazy world, but remember; NO ICE CREAM IN THE LOBBY.

50057720.review:
What makes Wuppo so special to me is that it has one of the most delightful, fully realized worlds I've ever encountered in a game, and it's so believable and immersive that it doesn't even feel like a game most of the time.

The level design is natural and doesn't feel like it specifically caters to the player's goals, like everything you come across could easily exist without you.  Time moves on its own, as do the hundreds of background characters who are all doing their own thing, living their own lives.  And the Wum you play as isn't some prophesied hero and doesn't even have any particularly noteworthy abilities by the end of the game; you're just one small citizen like anyone else in this big ol' world, which keeps the whole experience down-to-earth.

The heartbeat of this game also comes through in the way it progresses.  There aren't many moments that clearly define progress in the story, because just as much care and attention was put in the optional content as the main adventure, so it rarely feels like you're following a script.  The game still gives you suitable hints for making progress, but I didn't focus on them too much, because exploration is perhaps Wuppo's greatest focus.  Wandering around is often rewarding, if for no other reason than being able to witness more of the game's charming personality.

If I were to break down my minor gripes with Wuppo, one would be the combat.  The controls are very simple and generally effective, but dodging enemies and their attacks isn't always reasonable, so there were times when I wished for some sort of dash move.  Some of the enemy fire is also difficult to see, either because it's small or somewhat dark.  The inventory system is mildly cumbersome, and even though the button shortcuts help, they still leave something to be desired.  There were also a couple points in the story where I wasn't sure how to progress, although the game does remarkably well at keeping the flow most of the time, thanks to a number of its presented problems having multiple solutions.

Wuppo was clearly made with a vision.  It's a gem, and I recommend it to anyone who likes to explore and wants to smile.

There are already some great Wuppo reviews here, so I’d like to just share my personal perspective. 

I had so much fun. When I was playing with my gf, we were almost constantly chuckling or sincerely laughing, to the point when I had to pause the game. The dialogues are so light-hearted and fun, but at the same time I can’t help but think that some actual talent and passion was put into writing all of the jokes or just build the comical atmosphere. Almost all of the humor comes from the situations, characters and the setting itself. The colorful setting, optional side content (collectibles, achievements, hidden bosses, exploration), smooth platforming, very easy to follow structure... This is how this game works. It was a great thing, to be able to just start the game after a difficult day and return to it one day later for another hour or so. 48458283.review:
What an amazing experience! My wife and I love Wuppo!


The world built was truly unique and unforgettable. Its theme is by far the strongest draw card this game has to offer over other competing adventure games.

The little expressions the characters portrayed were simply perfect and up there with the great Sanrio characters like Gudetama.

I found the story surprisingly unpredictable because it didn't rely on the standard good/evil tropes.

The art style underpinned the whole experience and tells the player more about the world than the dialogue. An obliviously childlike yet functional utopia where you can believe that the worst part of your day will be spilling ice cream on the floor.... again. What a wholesome escape from reality.

Don't play this game for a challenging platformer or for the boss fights, this is all about exploring and getting absorbed in the world. My wife is new to gaming and this was a solid hit, the cute theme kept her interested and gave all the motivation needed to persevere with building up her platforming skills from scratch.

I really hope the devs got some solid recognition for this gem, it was such a refreshing change from the usual unimaginative cookie cutter games out there. Flaws (like jumping up to transition between screens) can be overlooked when a game is as lovable as this.

47860254.review:
What a great game! [I]Wuppo[/I] is a long, complex, and challenging platformer adventure. Though it's crammed with characters and lore (and many dialogs), it contains delightfully diverse gameplay throughout. Most of it is about finding or buying items and using them to solve puzzles, but there is also some good combat (many "boss" fights), platform jumping, and mundane activities such as fishing and ... waiting in line for a roller coaster.

All of this takes place in a deliberately silly and funny world that nevertheless makes sense. It's immersive enough to provide the backdrop for a coherent and engaging story, as good as you would find in game worlds that take themselves much, much more seriously. It seems that the creators worked hard to avoid any associations with our own world and its history, but if you squint just enough you'll see some subtle parody and commentary. Blink and it's gone, replaced with a pleasant and bubbly society in which life is carefree and strife is rather toothless.

I strongly recommend [I]Wuppo[/I], but it's still worth pointing out some faults to keep your expectations in check.

The music and sound design are consistently good. The visual style is ... consistent. It's charming, to be sure, but the choice to use a very low resolution and meager color palette are a sure sign of trying too hard to be "retro." There are less grating ways to be minimalistic. At times, this style can be frustrating, as when it's almost impossible to see where you are in a screen crowded with fast-moving low-res blobs. Could we at least have made the protagonist a unique color? I also was distracted by by the "helpful" bubble following you around to tell you how many hit points you have left. This should have been pushed to a corner of the screen.

The diverse gameplay does sometimes stumble. Pacing, for example, is uneven. The game starts with a lot of action platforming, but then slows down to spaced-out puzzle solving. It almost feels like you're in a different game. These styles should have been more intertwined.

Simple activities are sometimes made hard by obfuscating them via a lack of cues on how you're supposed to use items. Oh, I'm supposed to press a button, hold it pressed, and [I]then[/I] move? How about an in-game tutorial to explain these things? I only found out midway through the game that I can create shortcut buttons to access inventory items. This, too, should have been explained.

Finally, though [I]Wuppo[/I] is at heart a platformer, the controls are far too loose. It's too easy to slip and slide instead of neatly landing at your intended destination after jumping. Usually it's just annoying to have to go back and jump again, but during a boss fight it could be frustrating. Luckily, there are few enough boss fights and platforming areas to make this not too big of an issue. But if the balance were any different...

All in all, [I]Wuppo[/I] as a whole works so well that it's impossible to dwell on any of its faults. Grab your controller (or keyboard), set aside a few evenings, and let yourself be transported into its wacky world.

A very unique metroidvania game that took me by surprise.

I've not heard about the game before installing it and had actually no idea about the game play as well. To my surprise this did not turn out to be a lemmings clone but an interesting adventure platformer.

The visuals are a bit off putting at first with a hand drawn art style. But it somehow fits the games theme and if nothing else its consistent throughout. Some areas do look better others but luckily there's just a handful of ugly areas. But you do get used to it and as mentioned it does fit the game.

The game is a mixture of platformer and adventure game. The world has surprisingly quite deep lore despite being a little silly. But you do get attached to all the wums, fnakkers, blussers and other creatures inhabiting the world and they are a quite lovable bunch. The dialogs are well written and really funny at times.

Platforming is solid and the boss fights quite well designed. Challenging but rewarding with a very good boss design and variety. 

The adventuring is a bit old school. The game does not lead you by the hand and very often you're left to your own to figure things out. This can be both good and bad and I'll admit I was forced to use a guide here and there but figuring stuff on my own was very rewarding I'll admit.

So whats bad about the game. For starters it lacks a clear goal. For most of times it feels like giving you little goals but without proper motivation. And it feels like you're not sure what to do. You're forced to explore and eventually you figure out your next move but there's never a good "why" - things just sort of happen.

Some puzzles especially later on are extremely annoying, hard and frustrating making me drop a star from the final score. The last boss is unnecessarily too long and it's not always super easy to keep track of what's going on in the screen due to colorful chaos.

Overall it was a great ride though. A joy for sure and a feel-good kind of game.

47260987.review:
Wuppo is an adorable metroidvania full of charm. The characters can be pretty humourus and the game offers some dialogue choices for futher interaction (depending on your choice your wum even makes different expressions or mumbles the words at a different speed). The game does have a few standard enemies, but the combat mainly takes place in boss battles in which you essentially shoot blobs of gum at your foes. The boss fights were pretty memorable in that some of them popped up out of nowhere and the boss designs themselves are all distinguishable and unique. 

I would say the only issues I had with the game were relatively minor and mainly me nitpicking some things. I wish you could equip a usable item, such as a weapon, and some accessories at the same time, such as cosmetic outfits. 
I personally played using a controller and this made the game a bit more difficult as all movement is done with the left control stick (meaning no d-pad for precision movement) and equipment hotkeys are restricted to the d-pad and a few face buttons. There are quite a few items I liked to have on hand so having to go into the menu to rebind things was a little annoying sometimes. I also found the max jump height hard to achieve which made some platforms difficult to get over. These are all minor complaints on the whole though.

This game has so many nice details in it that just make me happy. I mentioned that your wum can change expression, but they can change color based on what they have done, such as turning a pale green for a while after getting nauseous. The game has an internal clock that events like the day/night cycle and some transportation arrival times are based on. The game also has some segments where you can wait in a line and the other characters get angry if you try to cut in front of them. There is also a bit of background lore that can be discovered, but it is entirely optional and isn't neccesary to enjoy the game.

Overall, if you want a cute, relaxing platformer to play and that isn't really that difficult or frustrating, then play Wuppo. You'll have a good time :D

Would rate a 4/5.

47168802.review:
There are a vast array of approaches taken to platformer design, but in general you pretty much know what you’re getting. With few exceptions you run, you jump, you collect powerups, you deal with enemies and traps, and you head for your goal. What exceptions there are can be eye-opening, and Wuppo is a prime example of just such a curveball. Presented as a platformer, edging dangerously close to a metroidvania, this charming little adventure is really just a day in the life of a simple little creature in their strange, fantastic world. And it just happens to be a day that could change everything forever.

You are a wum, a tiny, spherical creature on four stubby legs. You reside in the Wumhouse, a grand edifice in which you spend your days eating ice cream and watching TV. Unfortunately you’re a bit too slovenly about it for the management, which has you booted out into the wilderness to find a more accepting home. This sets you little wum on a grand odyssey, meeting other sentients like the rowdy blions and serene blussers, learning about the long and storied history of the world, and uncovering existential threats to the wum’s way of life. There are items to find, friends to help, credit to earn, and bosses to defeat on your journey, and what starts as a search for a new pad ends with the fate of the world resting on your adorable little dome.

Now, when I talk about a “grand odyssey”, you might be envisioning something like Hollow Knight or Ori where you’re exploring a vast, untamed land. That’s really not the case in Wuppo for a couple reasons. For one, the map is mostly concentrated around the actual settlements of the wums and their peers. When you get chucked from the Wumhouse you’ll do a little hiking through the forest and some caves, but after that it’s back to civilization and the towns and cities of the world for pretty much the rest of the game. Instead of spelunking and mountain climbing, you’ll be navigating the busy streets of Popo City, and exploring the villages of other species on the edges of wum society.

The other thing about Wuppo is that it’s more of an adventure game than anything. Combat tends to be the least of your concerns here, relegated to occasional enemy appearances and the isolated boss fights. There are plenty of those, mind you, but they’re spaced out between long sections of exploring, talking, and problem-solving. Your wum has a robust inventory of items they can wear on their tiny head and huck at other creatures for whatever reason, like returning lost hats or sharing food. You’ll get some clever hat-based devices like a cleaner that spreads suds for you to scrub and eat, and a newspaper launcher that delivers papers straight to willing heads. Most items are found or received but a few can be bought and sold, exchanging smurt or wondersplenk for goods like hats and food.

You may have noticed by now that there are some colorful names floating around in this one. Perhaps Wuppo’s greatest strength is in the world it has built for you to putter around in, full of rich histories and lore for its weirdly precious inhabitants. The optional filmstrip collectibles scattered throughout the game will teach you all about the shared history of the wums, blussers, splenkhakkers, and fnakers, as well as how Popo City and the Wumhouse came to be, where kneft come from, why the city runs on credit instead of smurt, and far more eclectic secrets than this. It’s all told with a familiar charm and hilarious writing, from the tall tales of Burt Smulder to the intense drive of Uberhenk. It’s adorable through and through, and encourages loads of exploration just to see more of the charm tucked away here.

The rich presentation helps a lot, because Wuppo can feel like a rather aimless game at times. Like I said, it’s not really an epic quest or a series of challenges, it’s just your little wum trying to find their place in the world. You’ll have objectives at any given time but they’re things like “find a new place to live” and “earn some credit”. It’ll take some effort to figure out what you should be doing next and how to do it, and in the early parts of the game before the full scope of events becomes clear, this can make it hard to stick with. My first attempt at playing Wuppo ended about two hours in, when I got stumped trying to get to Popo City and lost interest in the game. I needed a few clues to point me in the right direction the second time I played, but once I actually GOT to Popo City the game picked up significantly and kept me engaged all the way through the mind-bending conclusion.

You may also run afoul of technical issues on this one, owing to its GameMaker roots. Wuppo can be extremely temperamental about refresh rates, slowing down or speeding up to uncomfortable degrees. A few of the events can break as well, particularly the lines in Wondersplenk when you’re waiting to get on a ride. And that’s another thing, in the game’s quest to simulate an actual little society, there are things you need to wait in line for. The train between the Wumhouse and Popo City actually runs on a five-minute rotation, meaning you might be sitting at the station whistling (there’s a dedicated whistle button) as you arbitrarily wait to get on with the game.

These issues make Wuppo a bit more of a challenge to get into than more conventional platformers, but that’s also the beauty of it. Wuppo is a very different kind of platformer, one that’s not afraid to confuse you with its strange histories or unexpected conventions. It’s a game where you’re not a hero, you’re really just some little jerk who ends up making more of a difference than you’d ever expect, in ways you won’t be expecting either. It’s unique, which is rare for a platformer, but still manages to be unrelentingly fun. And that’s the thing, if you can get over the initial weirdness and hurdles, Wuppo rewards you with some of the happiest, most charming gameplay around.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]

The upgrades felt like a big part of the game when you got to them but it is so idiotically time consuming to get the money necessarry to buy the upgrades. It just feels so pointless for it to cost so much when there already is a lack of variety in the combat. 

The third problem was how easy the game was even when playing on hard. I might not be the demigraphic they are looking for but nothing felt very challanging at all and the few deaths felt more like bad boss design or bad leveldesign, the corridors with the jellyfishes for example. 

It is in my opinion impossible for me to recommend this game with these flaws.

45697037.review:
The Overwhelmingly Positive reviews ain't for show m8.

Wuppo is a genre-defying game that combines elements of metroidvania, shmups, platforming, puzzlers, bullet hell and RPGs, with a heavy focus on exploration in a largely open world. You'd think wew that sounds like a horrible mess but Wuppo combines all of this so effortlessly it's simply astonishing. It never gets repetitive thanks to its varied and polished gameplay.
Wuppo looks and sounds great and distinctive and has some of the best world-building I've ever seen in a video game. It's insanely cute and adorable without ever being childish. The humor is witty, sometimes subtle and always quirky. The game had me grinning like an idiot for the majority of my playtime. The premise and story are pretty basic but the world and characters just sucked me in for an immersive experience I haven't had in quite some time. There's so much to explore and silly stuff to do it's legit crazy. Everything just oozes with charme, character and soul. The attention to detail is extremely impressive.

I very rarely get post-game depression these days but Wuppo reminded me it's a thing. I never played anything like this before. I doubt there is anything like it in the first place.
The game was made by a team consisting of a whole two dudes from the Netherlands. Kudos to them. At first I thought yeah Wuppo is easily one of the best games ever developed in that country. But that doesn't do it justice; it's one of the best games ever made, period, and considering just how damn good Wuppo is, it's not even that bold a claim. It's a masterpiece.

- On sale: I *highly* recommend.

44842138.review:
Wuppo is a children sketchbook with lore, personality, and simple characters design brought to life. From the humorous branching dialogue, uplifting art, and simple gameplay Wuppo is guaranteed to bring you joy. 

There is an abundance of fun to have from exploring all of the different regions of the world that the game has to offer and learning about the different tribes that exist within the game. One of the best qualities of the game is that the entire world feels interconnected and creatively alive. Activities such as fishing, characters quest lines, and the collection of films accumulate together to greatly enhance the world building. The wide range of different hats, items, and food that you find also add to help the game feel constantly fresh and exciting.

While Wuppo excels at storytelling and world building it also lacks in level design. The large majority of areas within the world value creating an immersive environment rather than providing an area that is actually enjoyable for the player to navigate. Furthermore, while the combat is flashy with the ability to constantly shoot out a barrage of colors it does lack having any great depth.

In summary, if you want a simple, fun-filled, and charming experience I would absolutely recommend Wuppo.

The settings are varied and meaningful. Stepping off the train into Popocity gave me a strange feeling of entering a city unlike in any other game I've played (even something like GTA). The forests and caves and buildings are all great, full of detail and polish. And there are save "buckets" smartly placed just about everywhere, so while dying can and does happen quickly at times, especially facing one of the 19 bosses, you're almost never more than a few seconds away from where you left off. This game has zero filler. It doesn't make you do things twice. It's brisk. It's swift. 

The sense of progression is great. And I have no problem with the overall length of the game... I certainly didn't do everything, and I think I missed at least one area to visit, but I clocked about 7 hours at "The End" screen. I like that length. But the pacing does get a little weird at the end. It feels kind of abrupt. The quality of writing is so high throughout the game, I guess I expected some more things to call back to the beginning, some characters to show up, some of the game's early challenges to reappear in new ways. But it kinda just goes off an a tangent, and then - that's it! (And for a game about making friends, basically, it IS a bit odd that violence solves so many issues, but, oh well, it's fun.) I guess it's a testament to this game's quality that I did want more. I would have loved another large area or two to explore.

In almost every way, this game exudes polish. From its soundtrack to its menu interface to its inventory system and the items (and friends) you'll discover, it's constantly impressing me. Even the art, which may look a bit sloppy at first glance, has a structure and consistency that grew on me rapidly, even evoking a bit of Yoshi's Island for me (especially the larger-than-life bosses). I would definitely recommend this game, and I look forward to more projects from Knuist & Perzik!

Wuppo is a cute metroidvania where you play a small little creatue called a Wum who lives with a load of other Wums in a giant hotel. Unfortunately your Wum is a lazy guy who gets kicked out of the hotel for spilling ice cream all over the halls. If you think that description of the games start is strange, well it pretty much sums up the strange but likeable world of Wuppo.

Most of the game is spent exploring different locations, completing quests and fighting bosses. Most of the combat in the game revolves around the bosses. Early in the game you get a gu which shoots colourful gumballs which you use to fight the bosses. The boss fights are pretty enjoyable. They offer a decent challenge initially without being too punishing, though once you've figured out the bosses attack patterns they are easy enough to beat.

You'll meet a lot of strange and quirky characters throughout the game and some interesting locations like the Wondersplenk, a big theme park, and Popo City which is an underground city full of Wums. I enjoyed the games artstyle which looks right out of a childs colouring book and the music suits the game perfectly.

My only criticism is that there were a couple of occasions where I wasn't really sure how to proceed. The game doesn't always do a good job of nudging you in the right direction.

Overall though I quite liked Wuppo. It's a strange little game but it such a cute and charming game that it won me over quickly.

44076010.review:
I feel terrible for giving this game a bad review because it was clearly a passion project, but ultimately I can't recommend this to anyone.

First off; no, it's not a metroidvania. It was given that tag by people who I assume have never played a metroidvania in their lives. You can upgrade your weapon but it's never useful besides one upgrade that has a chance to make your next shot do more damage. There's one other weapon you can get (the bazooka) but as far as I can remember it has no upgrades and a fully charged from it does not out-damage the upgrade I mentioned earlier.

The game's also strangely cryptic, giving you almost no hints for certain puzzles that are required to progress, such as one where you have to use the bazooka to splatter paint on a canvas. However, it HAS to be in a certain color and the color that the bazooka fires is entirely randomized. You're barely told any of this and my solution was to randomly shoot all over the area and rub up against everything until something magically happened. 

That wouldn't be a deal-breaker if it wasn't for the world design. Wuppo, I think, is a prime example of how NOT to design game worlds. The train that takes you to most major locations in the game is on a real-time schedule, meaning you have to literally queue for the train, get on, and then wait several minutes before you arrive somewhere else (there's a mini-game you can play and a coffee shop you can visit but you only get like a minute at that coffee shop and the conductor yells at you if you take too long.) It adds absolutely nothing other than tedium.

A small aside I want to mention; around two or three bosses I fought in either playthrough had instant kill attacks that you would never know were coming until you already got killed by them.

I never finished Wuppo despite its cute artstyle being very appealing to me, and I tried earnestly to give it two playthroughs. Ultimately if you want a game that's somewhat similar in style (an open but linear 2D platformer with a neat artstyle) I'd seriously recommend you go play Outland. This game just wasn't worth it to me.

(also also: the entire game is about "a lost Wum searching for a new home" but if you go back to the hotel at the beginning of the game, the guy there just says you can have your house back. Great narrative!)

43278191.review:
A cute round creature called a Wum, spills ice-cream in the hallway of the Wumhouse. He gets thrown out and needs to go looking for a new home, in a strange world with all kinds of creatures. Adventure awaits him with monsters and dangers ahead, but he also makes a lot of friends on the way.

This game’s story is quite interesting, with lots of funny dialogue with random NPC’s. The gameplay is something of a mix between a platformer and an adventure RPG. You jump around and shoot monsters with your gumgumgun. The controls aren’t always as great, but that doesn’t damage the experience much. The graphics are unique and cute. There are lots of really fun puzzles in the game, but some of them are a bit too hard to solve in my opinion. The boss fights are fun too, though sometimes a bit quirky. There even is an extra game mode called Boss Run, where you can try to defeat all the bosses in the game (19 in total). 

The soundtrack of this game is amazing and cute too, and compliments the setting of the game very well. Wuppo also has a lot of collectibles, including hats, weapon upgrades, film strips (slide shows with cool lore and solutions to puzzles) and happiness points (your life total). These things make the game much more interesting, especially for a completionist like myself. 

Another thing that I really like about this game, is that it is made by Dutch people. In the game, lots of names are made of two different weird-sounding Dutch words, forming one gibberish word. Funny examples of this are Smakmoffel, the Bankkrent, the Denksnavel, the Allesweter, etcetera, etcetera. Games like these make me proud to be Dutch.

This game is incredibly fun to play, due to the cuteness, wholesomeness, the cool dialogue, the puzzles and the bosses. The graphics, the gameplay and the soundtrack are all amazing. I would definitely recommend people to play this game. 8/10. Very enjoyable.

I had a feeling that this game just wastes a lot of my time. There is an in-game time and some events happen periodically or at some time of the day and you just have to wait for them. Until I stumbled upon a 'chapter' where you have to score points for something to happen and you get these points by doing some quests. But there aren't many quests and you are expected to do some of them many times to score enough points. Or you can just wait and the amount of points is slowly increasing, even when you do nothing at all. This made me quit - I had zero fun when doing these quests. I did a few quests for 2-3 times, because I was hoping something will finally happen and I can move on. It didn't. I thought I missed something so I even checked a walkthrough that only confirmed that I'm supposed to just do these quests until I get enough points.
Second issue was lack of a clear goal (only sometimes, but still) that again, kind of wasted your time as you walked and hoped to stumble upon anything that will tell you what to do.

So, in the end, I regretfully can not recommend it.

41993286.review:
WUPPO - 9/10

What is it?
-----------
A 2D puzzle platformer with lots of varied bosses to take on, different areas, quest solving and so much more.

What do you do?
-----------------
You'll be journeying from A to B back to A to B for the majority of the game solving puzzles, talking to LOTS of people, completing quests, killing bad guys and fighting huge bosses. Gameplay is super varied and it's very hard to explain all that you'll be doing. It's kind of like a 2D Super Mario except with one giant world. There is also a boss rush mode after beating the game with alot of interesting and unique mechanics that are not part of the main game.

Is it fun?
-----------
For the first few hours not really but as you get further into the game and start exploring more and more the game becomes very interesting with gameplay becoming more and more diverse, bigger areas opening up, more weapon upgrades and just so many things to explore. It's very different to alot of other platformers.

Is the story good?
------------------
You play as Wuppo, a small fluffball who gets kicked out of his house for eating too much ice cream. While trying to earn your way back into the house you'll unravel an adventure in the making, meet all kinds of different races, journey to the thriving Pop City and ultimately save the world. Or will you? Yes, the story is great.

Is the design good?
-------------------
10/10. While the handrawn graphics may take a while to get used to there is no denying the soundtrack is absolutely stunning. World design is a 10/10 with every part of the game world being interconnected with each other. Pop City is especially amazing, you'll see thousands of different furballs going about their day. Never once do you feel like some kind of unique hero, you'll always feel like you're part of a living breathing world that will move on without you which is astounding and very welcoming.

Is the game hard?
-----------------
Not really. Some of the bosses are difficult if you don't have the right weapon and some of the puzzles are tough to solve but ultimately I wouldn't consider the game hard (except for the final boss).

Are the controls responsive?
----------------------------
Hmmmm yeah i'd say so. There always seemed to be a delay between my button press and the action especially when it came to firing my gun but movement was fluid and I had no complaints about the layout.

Is it repetitive?
-----------------
Boss Rush is but the main story isn't. The game constantly throws interesting things on you that keep the pacing at a great level and make you want to proceed.

Is it aggravating?
------------------
Only the tough boss battles can be aggravating. However I did feel it was tedious having to travel such long distances on foot to do specific things. There were times when the majoirty of the quests had you walking from one of the beginning areas to an almost end game area and it took a long time. There is no fast travel so you'll spend alot of the late game doing ALOT of relatively slow paced walking.

Does it have any replayability?
-------------------------------
Main story not really unless you super enjoyed it but I can absolutely see myself coming back to it in a few years. Boss Rush is replayable (that's its purpose) but can be frustrating and not really worth playing.

Is the achievement list varied?
-------------------------------
Very. Most of the achievements are collectible related but you get alot for doing different things during the story mode. There is also a bunch of boss rush achievements that are really varied but pretty difficult.

Are the achievements hard?
--------------------------
Boss Rush achievements are, but the majority of the ones earned through the main story isn't. The hardest one is collecting all the "happiness" (collectibles earned through doing quests or doing specific actions). There is no tracker for them and there is over a 100 points so you'll never know which one you missed.

Did I like it?
--------------
I loved it, alot. Apart from the final boss and the slow intro I thought the game was an amazing example of how game should be made. Also, the game is REALLY funny.

Should you buy it?
------------------
If you like good stories and 2D platformers at ALL, then yes. Otherwise the long playtime coupled with some frustrating parts may not make this a game for you.

41350321.review:
Wuppo's a really hard one for me to review. For the first half of the game, I was infuriated by it. How is it so well reviewed on Steam, and paced so horrendously? The music can be extremely repetitive, the combat doesn't feel great, doesn't have a lot of variety to it, and a lot of the bosses seem to have too much health. And sorry, what? You have to wait in fucking line? What?! I couldn't play it anymore, I just didn't get it; The game was bad. I put the game down, and didn't pick it back up again for what was probably a couple months. 

I played Paper Mario in that time, and finally returned to Wuppo afterwards. I originally was recommended the game because I'm a fan of Metroidvanias. Well, it's not that at all. The best genre I think I could tag it to would be Action/Adventure, but really the best service you can probably do is compare it to Paper Mario (or at least the first two games in that series). Paper Mario's got its own set of rules for the universe, its own creative cast of quirky characters, and is an adventure that connects you to them. Wuppo is like that, but take the universe and the quirkiness and crank it up to the maximum. Don't even get me started talking about... What was it? Plump? Fnuist? And then there's the Fnakkers, and the Blussers, and... Well it's all entirely unique, and very weird. And you really do learn almost every minute detail about the world by the end. It's really interesting in that way, and I can't think of much else like it. That, along with the great writing and art makes every character you meet really endearing, and this insane world somehow believable. And for that, I recommend Wuppo.

So yeah, you heard me right. I recommend a game that for a good while I passionately hated. And it's not because I think I just had the wrong mindset, it's because the latter half of the game that I played made it all worth it. I think it's still laden with flaws early on, but I think there's still plenty to love after that. Here's what you need to know so that you can hopefully enjoy the game when I didn't:
1. It's not a Metroidvania, it's a weird adventure where you sometimes shoot at stuff, and other times give items to characters.
2. Explore just enough as to not get bored, so that you can get the filmstrips and learn more about the world and get some cash on the side. Anything extra is too much until you're later on in the game.
3. The best place to finally stop and start smelling the roses is [spoiler]Popo City[/spoiler]. Really, go for filmstrips and explore or min/max no further than you find enjoyable before you get to this place.

So... Good luck; Have fun.

41275988.review:
The following review is written by my boyfriend YouritheKing, with whom I have shared this game via Family Sharing. 
Account link: http://steamcommunity.com/id/YouritheKing

A cute round creature called a Wum, spills ice-cream in the hallway of the Wumhouse. He gets thrown out and needs to go looking for a new home, in a strange world with all kinds of creatures. Adventure awaits him with monsters and dangers ahead, but he also makes a lot of friends on the way.

This game’s story is quite interesting, with lots of funny dialogue with random NPC’s. The gameplay is something of a mix between a platformer and an adventure RPG. You jump around and shoot monsters with your gumgumgun. The controls aren’t always as great, but that doesn’t damage the experience much. The graphics are unique and cute. There are lots of really fun puzzles in the game, but some of them are a bit too hard to solve in my opinion. The boss fights are fun too, though sometimes a bit quirky. There even is an extra game mode called Boss Run, where you can try to defeat all the bosses in the game (19 in total). 

The soundtrack of this game is amazing and cute too, and compliments the setting of the game very well. Wuppo also has a lot of collectibles, including hats, weapon upgrades, film strips (slide shows with cool lore and solutions to puzzles) and happiness points (your life total). These things make the game much more interesting, especially for a completionist like myself. 

Another thing that I really like about this game, is that it is made by Dutch people. In the game, lots of names are made of two different weird-sounding Dutch words, forming one gibberish word. Funny examples of this are Smakmoffel, the Bankkrent, the Denksnavel, the Allesweter, etcetera, etcetera. Games like these make me proud to come from the Netherlands.

This game is incredibly fun to play, due to the cuteness, wholesomeness, the cool dialogue, the puzzles and the bosses. The graphics, the gameplay and the soundtrack are all amazing. I would definitely recommend people to play this game. 8/10. Very enjoyable.

40472838.review:
This is an incredible sweet and wonderful adventure game. It's fairly easy but the game is not without it's problems. In some aspects it's similar to Kirby. It has a lovely atmosphere with great music. The artstyle and animation is simple and adorable. The story is straight forward and easy to follow.

Gameplay is a mixture of platforming, puzzle solving, and basic action shooter. 

Controls are simple and easy to get to too. The hotkey for items feels like it could be improved a little. I'd have liked mouse button support for this. Overall it feels pretty tight on controls. 

Combat is pretty easy. You don't know how many hits an enemy needs to take to kill them. This can cause some close shaves. Being swarmed is the easiest way to die.

Using healing items is risky as they have an activation time. If it's not hotkey'd then you aren't pretty much done for in a fight. To open up your items menu you have to hit tab and then left click on the blue icon. This is simple enough but if it's during a fight then expect to get hit a lot whilst doing this. 

Platforming can be frustrating at times. Some things look like platforms but sometimes they aren't. There is no fall damage but that may mean back tracking. Other than that it's fairly easy there is no feeling of slippery surfaces etc.

Exploration of the world by running around or with side quests is rewarded with extra happiness, back story, weapon upgrades etc. 

I hope more people pick this up and enjoy this delightful little adventure.

40380077.review:
What a surprisingly delightful, charming, and creative game.

Wuppo is exactly as whimsical and silly as it sounds, and it put a big dumb smile on my face every time I sat down to play it.

It is equal parts adventure, puzzling and platforming, and has some pretty decent boss fights. There are so many things that make this game unique, like the fine polish and nice little details you might find in a Nintendo title. But what I like most of all is that it feels like someone sat down a child and had them describe an entire game, world building and all, and let someone make it.

And I mean that in a really good way! Every single place and thing feels like a natural extension of the last. Every bit is silly, but you still get the sense of adventure during your escalating escapedes. If you give it a shot and enjoy it, take it upon yourself to beat the whole thing. That's not an ending I'll be forgetting anytime soon!

If I had this game as a kid, it would be a game I look back on often and think of quite fondly.

Imagine if game were to be designed by a clinically insane manic-depressive.

There is also an additional boss-run gamemode which provides a nice challenge and some extra replayability, especially if you enjoy acheivement hunting or competing to out-best your your friends.
